urn:contentItem:6GMW-CN03-RRSV-82WK-00000-00Xinhua Middle East news summary at 2200 GMT, Sept. 12025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSXinhua Middle East news summary at 2200 GMT, Sept. 1Guo Yage

BAGHDAD -- Iraqi Prime Minister Mohammed Shia' al-Sudani on Monday inaugurated the renowned al-Nuri Mosque and its al-Hadba minaret in the northern city of Mosul after their reconstruction. Al-Sudani said the terrorist attack that destroyed the al-Hadba minaret is an attempt to kill the spirit of Mosul and sever its connection to its glorious history, according to a statement by his media office. (Iraq-Al-Nuri Mosque-Reopening) - - - - BEIRUT -- Lebanon and Syria agreed Monday to form joint committees to address the issues of border security and missing persons, during a meeting between the two sides in Beirut.

A Syrian delegation, led by Mohammed Taha Al-Ahmad, director of Arab Affairs at Syria's foreign affairs authorities, met with Lebanon's Deputy Prime Minister Tarek Mitri. (Lebanon-Syria-Border Security Cooperation) - - - - ISTANBUL -- A forest fire in Denizli province, western Türkiye, reached residential areas, burning houses and prompting evacuations, authorities said on Monday. Governor Omer Faruk Coskun said on the social media platform X that all available resources had been mobilized and that efforts were continuing to bring the fire under control. (Türkiye-Forest Fire-Evacuations) - - - - TEHRAN -- Iran's atomic chief said on Sunday that two inspectors from the UN nuclear watchdog oversaw a fuel replacement process at the Bushehr nuclear power plant. Mohammad Eslami, head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, told state television the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) inspectors were allowed to supervise the work with the approval of Iran's Supreme National Security Council and under a law passed in June to restrict cooperation with the agency. (Iran-Nuclear Facility-IAEA Inspection) Enditem

urn:contentItem:6GC6-MGN3-RSH5-34PR-00000-00PM Modi praises Odisha women for creating forest fire awareness through kirtans2025-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisPM Modi praises Odisha women for creating forest fire awareness through kirtansBhubaneswar

Bhubaneswar, July 27 -- Prime Minister Narendra Modi in his 'Mann Ki Baat' programme today praised a group of women from Odisha's Keonjhar district, who are spreading awareness regarding forest fires through kirtans.

"The most beautiful glimpse of India's diversity is found in our folk songs and traditions, and our bhajans and kirtans are a part of this. But have you ever heard that people are made aware of forest fires through kirtans? You may not believe it, but amazing work is happening in Keonjhar district of Odisha. Here, there is a group named Radhakrishna Sankirtan Mandali," the PM said.

"Along with devotion, today, this group is also chanting the mantra of environmental protection. The inspiration behind this initiative is Pramila Pradhan ji. To protect the forest and the environment, she has added new lyrics and new messages to traditional songs. Her troupe went from village to village. Through songs, people were made to understand how much damage forest fires cause. This example reminds us that our folk traditions are not something of the past; they still have the power to give direction to society," said Modi.

He also hailed a group of tribal women in the Mayurbhanj district for reviving the Santhali saree.

"There is a similar success story in Mayurbhanj, Odisha. Here, more than 650 tribal women have revived the Santhali saree. Now these women are earning thousands of rupees every month. They are not just making clothes, but also carving their own identity," he said.

urn:contentItem:6GRG-9T13-S0GH-P4MN-00000-00Three municipalities in Cundinamarca register forest fires2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisThree municipalities in Cundinamarca register forest fires


Authorities attended three emergencies in the municipalities of Nilo, Sasaima and Ricaurte. No injuries were reported.
Relief agencies of the department of Cundinamarca have been working since Friday night, September 12, to put out three forest fires reported in rural areas of the municipalities of Nilo, Ricaurte and Sasaima. Although the emergency response work is progressing satisfactorily and no injuries have been reported, the loss of vegetation and the impact on fauna is considerable.


The conflagrations
After 6:00 p.m. on Friday, the volunteer fire department of Nilo received a report of a forest fire that was consuming a hill in a rural area of the municipality, specifically in the Los Curos area, in a sector known as Las Flores.
10 units of firefighters and officials of Risk Management of the municipality arrived at the point, in limits with the San Bartolo village, and after 09:00 p.m., according to the governor, Jorge Emilio Rey, the emergency was partially controlled.
"It is reported the affectation of about 15 hectares of native forest. Thanks to the work of ten firefighting units of the municipality, the fire is 70% under control. For the safety of the personnel, operations will be resumed early tomorrow morning until the fire is completely extinguished," confirmed the governor.
According to local firefighters, the emergency, which may have been caused intentionally, seriously affected native vegetation and caused the displacement of wildlife.
On the other hand, in the municipality of Ricaurte, a fire was confirmed in the El Paso sector. Departmental authorities activated a Unified Command Post (PMU) to coordinate the response. Thanks to the joint efforts of the fire departments of Tocaima, Girardot and Agua de Dios, after 11:00 a.m. on Saturday, September 13, 98% of the emergency was under control.
Although the flames have been extinguished, work continues in the area to liquidate hot spots.
Finally, in a rural area of the municipality of Sasaima, in the vicinity of the Lanillo and Pilaca villages, another forest fire was reported which, according to the most recent report, was 85% under control.
Authorities continue to monitor the affected areas and call on citizens to prevent new conflagrations, especially in this dry season, when the risk of forest fires increases. Likewise, progress is being made in the evaluation of environmental damages and in the recovery actions of the damaged areas.
For more news from the capital and Cundinamarca, visit the Bogotá section of El Espectador.

urn:contentItem:6G00-K603-RSBS-G06K-00000-00Reports from Nanjing Forestry University Add New Study Findings to Research in Physics (YOLOv8n-SMMP: A Lightweight YOLO Forest Fire Detection Model)2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisPHYSICSReports from Nanjing Forestry University Add New Study Findings to Research in Physics (YOLOv8n-SMMP: A Lightweight YOLO Forest Fire Detection Model)


2025 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Physics Daily News -- Current study results on physics have been published. According to news reporting out of Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Global warming has driven a marked increase in forest fire occurrences, underscoring the critical need for timely and accurate detection to mitigate fire-related losses."


Funders for this research include Frontier Technologies R&D Program of Jiangsu.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "Existing forest fire detection algorithms face limitations in capturing flame and smoke features in complex natural environments, coupled with high computational complexity and inadequate lightweight design for practical deployment. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an enhanced forest fire detection model, YOLOv8n-SMMP (SlimNeck-MCA-MPDIoU-Pruned), based on the YOLO framework. Key innovations include the following: introducing the SlimNeck solution to streamline the neck network by replacing conventional convolutions with Group Shuffling Convolution (GSConv) and substituting the Cross-convolution with 2 filters (C2f) module with the lightweight VoV-based Group Shuffling Cross-Stage Partial Network (VoV-GSCSP) feature extraction module; integrating the Multi-dimensional Collaborative Attention (MCA) mechanism between the neck and head networks to enhance focus on fire-related regions; adopting the Minimum Point Distance Intersection over Union (MPDIoU) loss function to optimize bounding box regression during training; and implementing selective channel pruning tailored to the modified network architecture. The experimental results reveal that, relative to the baseline model, the optimized lightweight model achieves a 3.3% enhancement in detection accuracy (mAP@0.5), slashes the parameter count by 31%, and reduces computational overhead by 33%."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "These advancements underscore the model's superior performance in real-time forest fire detection, outperforming other mainstream lightweight YOLO models in both accuracy and efficiency."
For more information on this research see: YOLOv8n-SMMP: A Lightweight YOLO Forest Fire Detection Model. Fire, 2025,8(5):183. (Fire - https://www.mdpi.com/journal/fire). The publisher for Fire is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/fire8050183.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Nianzu Zhou, College of Information Science and Technology and Artificial Intelligence, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Demin Gao, Zhengli Zhu.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Physics.

urn:contentItem:6G06-JC93-RRR3-51RR-00000-00Research from Nanjing Forestry University Broadens Understanding of Sensor Research (Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv11n)2025-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - SENSOR RESEARCHResearch from Nanjing Forestry University Broadens Understanding of Sensor Research (Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv11n)


2025 JUN 06 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Math Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in sensor research. According to news reporting out of Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "To address issues in traditional forest fire detection models, such as large parameter sizes, slow detection speed, and unsuitability for resource-constrained devices, this paper proposes a forest fire detection method, FEDS-YOLOv11n, based on an improved YOLOv11n model."


Financial supporters for this research include The Major Project of The National Public Welfare Industry Research Special Program; The Jiangsu Province Postgraduate Research And Innovation Program.
Our news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "First, the C3k2 module was redesigned using the FasterBlock module, replacing C3k2 with C3k2-Faster in both the Backbone network and Neck section to achieve a lightweight model design. Second, an EMA attention mechanism was introduced into the C3k2-Faster module in the Backbone, replacing C3k2-Faster with C3k2-Faster-EMA to compensate for the accuracy loss in small-object detection caused by the lightweight design. Third, the original upsampling module in the Neck was replaced with the lightweight dynamic upsampling operator DySample. Finally, the detection head was improved using the SEAM attention module, replacing the original Detect head with SEAMHead, which enables better handling of occluded objects. The experimental results show that compared to YOLOv11n, the proposed FEDS-YOLOv11n achieves improvements of 0.9% in precision (P), 1.9% in recall ®, 2.1% in mean precision at IoU 0.5 (mAP@0.5), and 2.3% in mean precision at IoU 0.5-0.95 (mAP@0.5-0.95). Additionally, the number of parameters is reduced by 21.32%, GFLOPs are reduced by 26.98%, and FPS increases from 48.2 to 71.8."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The FEDS-YOLOv11n model ensures high accuracy while maintaining lower computational complexity and faster inference speed, making it suitable for real-time forest fire detection applications."
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv11n. Sensors, 2025,25(10):2989. (Sensors - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/sensors). The publisher for Sensors is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/s25102989.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Kangqian Zhou, School of Mechanical and Electronic Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Shuihai Jiang.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Algorithms, Sensor Research, Technology.

urn:contentItem:6G9H-PG43-RRSG-W010-00000-00Forest fire haze from Indonesia detected in Malaysia2025-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSForest fire haze from Indonesia detected in MalaysiaPEKANBARU, Indonesia

PEKANBARU, Indonesia — Haze from forest and peatland fires in some parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra island was detected in Malaysia on Sunday, officials said.

Forest and peat fires are an annual problem in Indonesia that strain relations with neighboring countries. In recent years, smoke from the fires has blanketed parts of Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia and southern Thailand.

A number of areas in Indonesia's Riau province were still covered by thick haze, although choking smoke had not been registered in the provincial capital of Pekanbaru, said Riau deputy police chief Adrianto Jossy Kusumo.

He said more than 140 forest and peatland fires were reported in the province. Rokan Hilir and Rokan Hulu districts were the worst hit areas by fires that burned about 46 hectares in the two districts, resulting in heavy haze pollution across the area that reduced visibility to as low as one kilometer (half a mile).

The figure for fires was down from 294 hotspots on Saturday after authorities managed to extinguish the fire in several places, Kusumo said.

He said haze has caused the air quality in Riau to worsen, “but overall it has not disrupted people’s lives in other areas of the province.”

However, based on satellite imagery from the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency in Pekanbaru, haze was detected moving northeastward and reaching Kemang Bay in Malaysia’s Negeri Sembilan state, said a forecaster on duty, Gita Dewi.

“It showed the haze was moving by the wind to cross Malaysia,” Dewi said. She said hotspots were also detected in other parts of West Sumatra and North Sumatra provinces, but Riau recorded the highest number of hotspots on the island of Sumatra.

Forest fires on Sumatra and Borneo islands often break out in the region during dry spells, smothering parts of nearby Singapore and Malaysia in haze.

In 2023, Indonesia which often sends apologies to its neighbors over the haze, denied that its fires were causing blankets of haze in Malaysia.

The Indonesian government usually blames plantation owners and traditional farmers for illegally setting the fires for land-clearing.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VNS3-RRPC-G4JM-00000-00Fire in Concepción: Mayor states that in 2024 they did not receive funds from approved loans2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisFire in Concepción: Mayor states that in 2024 they did not receive funds from approved loans


After confirming the first forest fire in Concepción, Santa Cruz, Mayor Mauricio Viera denounced this Thursday, September 11, 2025, that his municipality did not receive any economic resources from the credits approved in 2024 for the attention of these disasters.


"Very concerned about our first forest fire in this management. We have worked in prevention, we did not want to reach this situation, it is an uninhabitable place, there is no way to arrive by land, only by air", said the authority, after confirming that the fire originated in an inaccessible area.
Questioning to the central government
The mayor said he was surprised by the central government's insistence that Concepción be declared a disaster in the past. He explained that on August 13 he received an official letter requesting this declaration, when the first fire was activated only on August 28.
"It worries me that this declaration serves to continue giving credits in the name of Concepción", he said, pointing out that the president of the Senate sent them a note on May 20, 2025 asking if they received economic resources to attend to the fires. "It bothers me. It says 'that they have given us 1,403 million dollars and 300 million euros (in 2024)'." Which is totally false," denounced Viera.
The authority also questioned that, during last year's fires, the local population had to contribute with food for police and military displaced in the area. "Where did that money go, where did it go?" he questioned.
"With total forcefulness that not a single boliviano arrived to the coffers of the Municipal Government of Concepción," the mayor reiterated.
Coordination to put out the fire
Regarding the efforts to quell the fire in Concepción, the Mayor's Office is coordinating with the Santa Cruz Government, through the Deputy Governor Daniel Velásquez, who confirmed that they conducted a flyover in the area, which allowed detecting a clandestine runway and warned of limitations due to lack of fuel.
The deputy governor added that in protected areas there are activities linked to drug trafficking and that, on this occasion, they observed how from a light aircraft burning tires were thrown to spread the fire.
Lack of communication
Viera clarified that he did not receive any call from the Vice Ministry of Civil Defense to coordinate actions regarding the fire.
The post Fire in Concepción: Mayor affirms that in 2024 they did not receive resources from approved credits first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

Future of boss in major doubt after relationship with owner breaks down

NUNO ESPIRITO SANTO has placed his Nottingham Forest future in grave doubt by declaring: "There is no smoke without fire."

In a remarkable press conference to preview tomorrow's trip to Crystal Palace, the Reds boss (right) claimed his relationship with owner Evangelos Marinakis has broken down to such an extent it may be beyond repair.

The Portuguese signed a new deal in June, having guided Forest into Europe for the first time in 30 years, but last week he raged that his squad was not deep enough.

Four new signings have swiftly arrived, with Marinakis (above) spending about £100million.

But Nuno has revealed that what used to be a "respectful relationship" between the pair is now "not so good."

He added: "I have always had a very good relationship with the owner.

"Last season was very, very, very close, almost on a daily TURN TO PAGE 58

FROM BACK PAGE basis. This season, not so well. But I always believe that dialogue and what you say or your opinion, is always valid.

"My concern is the squad and the season that we have ahead of us, but our relationship has changed.

"Everybody at the club should be together, but this is not the reality."

Asked for his thoughts around a possible sacking, he added: "Where there's smoke, there's fire, so I know how things work. But I'm here to do my job. I understand because I'm worried. I'm the first one to be concerned."

Pressed further to explain why he was worried his future might be in doubt, Nuno told BBC Radio: "Nothing has been said to me. I'm just addressing the rumours because we are talking, and this is public - and when something is public, I think we should talk about it. How do I feel about it?

"I feel sorry. I think about the players, because they were aware of things in the morning, and I could see it in their faces.

"I react as I think I should - as I always have in my life - by facing things and doing the best I can until the very last moment. I appreciate the respect and the feelings the fans have towards me. When I go out, I feel this love - and I just have to thank them."

Nuno and Marinakis clashed on the pitch after a 2-2 draw against Leicester at the City Ground in May (left).

Yongan Fire Safety Group launches advanced forest fire trucks designed for rough terrain, remote firefighting, and night operations, featuring 4x4 off-road capability, large water tanks, and elevated lighting for effective wildfire rescue.

China, May 20, 2025 -- Yongan Fire Safety Group Co., Ltd., one of China's most trusted fire truck manufacturers with over 30 years of industry experience, has announced the launch of its latest line of forest fire trucks specially designed to combat wildfires in remote and rugged environments.

Unlike standard city fire engines that rely on paved roads and nearby hydrants, these forest fire trucks are engineered for off-road terrain, long-duration water supply, and nighttime operation, making them a critical asset in wildfire emergencies.

Built to Conquer the Wild

Forest fires often ignite in hard-to-reach areas where conventional fire trucks can't operate. Yongan's forestry fire trucks are built on the durable SINOTRUCK HOWO 4x4 chassis, providing excellent traction, torque, and stability on muddy, steep, or narrow trails. With high ground clearance and electric traction systems, these vehicles can clear fallen debris, avoid obstacles, and self-recover when stuck-ensuring rescue teams remain mobile and safe.

Reliable Water Supply for Remote Firefighting

To address the lack of water sources in wilderness areas, each truck is equipped with a 5-ton onboard water tank-enough to support extended firefighting missions without the need for refills. The integrated high-pressure pumps can push water uphill, allowing teams to combat flames even in mountainous terrain.

Illuminating the Fight at Night

Since wildfires often burn through the night, Yongan fire trucks are fitted with elevating lighting systems that provide powerful, wide-area illumination. This helps firefighters maintain visibility of terrain, hazards, and fire conditions, even in complete darkness.

Designed for Real-World Rescue

'Our forest fire trucks are purpose-built to perform in the toughest conditions,' said a spokesperson for Yongan Fire Safety Group. 'From massive water tanks to powerful off-road capability and night lighting systems, these vehicles are ready for anything.'

Whether you're a fire department, emergency response team, or fire equipment dealer, Yongan's forest fire trucks are a reliable solution for modern wildfire rescue operations.

urn:contentItem:6G9H-RPJ3-RVJW-515T-00000-00Forest fire haze from Indonesia detected in Malaysia2025-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSForest fire haze from Indonesia detected in MalaysiaPEKANBARU, Indonesia

PEKANBARU, Indonesia (AP) — Haze from forest and peatland fires in some parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra island was detected in Malaysia on Sunday, officials said.

Forest and peat fires are an annual problem in Indonesia that strain relations with neighboring countries. In recent years, smoke from the fires has blanketed parts of Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia and southern Thailand.

A number of areas in Indonesia's Riau province were still covered by thick haze, although choking smoke had not been registered in the provincial capital of Pekanbaru, said Riau deputy police chief Adrianto Jossy Kusumo.

He said more than 140 forest and peatland fires were reported in the province. Rokan Hilir and Rokan Hulu districts were the worst hit areas by fires that burned about 46 hectares in the two districts, resulting in heavy haze pollution across the area that reduced visibility to as low as one kilometer (half a mile).

The figure for fires was down from 294 hotspots on Saturday after authorities managed to extinguish the fire in several places, Kusumo said.

He said haze has caused the air quality in Riau to worsen, “but overall it has not disrupted people’s lives in other areas of the province.”

However, based on satellite imagery from the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency in Pekanbaru, haze was detected moving northeastward and reaching Kemang Bay in Malaysia’s Negeri Sembilan state, said a forecaster on duty, Gita Dewi.

“It showed the haze was moving by the wind to cross Malaysia,” Dewi said. She said hotspots were also detected in other parts of West Sumatra and North Sumatra provinces, but Riau recorded the highest number of hotspots on the island of Sumatra.

Forest fires on Sumatra and Borneo islands often break out in the region during dry spells, smothering parts of nearby Singapore and Malaysia in haze.

In 2023, Indonesia which often sends apologies to its neighbors over the haze, denied that its fires were causing blankets of haze in Malaysia.

The Indonesian government usually blames plantation owners and traditional farmers for illegally setting the fires for land-clearing.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-STB3-RTKD-H4J4-00000-00Wildlife offences in Bhutan fall, but timber extraction remains dominant2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisWildlife offences in Bhutan fall, but timber extraction remains dominantReporting by:BORNEO BULLETINTHIMPHU( BORNEO BULLETIN/ANN)

THIMPHU( BORNEO BULLETIN/ANN) - Wildlife and forest-related offences recorded in the Forest Information Reporting and Monitoring System (FIRMS) dropped sharply in 2024, falling to 749 cases from 1,295 the previous year-a 42 percent decline. The drop extends a four-year slide since the pandemic peak of 1,917 cases in 2020.

Officials caution, however, that the figures reflect only detected cases. Undetected poaching and trafficking are believed to remain higher, particularly in remote and inaccessible areas.

Illegal timber extraction continues to dominate Bhutan's wildlife-crime landscape. Of the 749 cases logged last year, 488-nearly two-thirds-were linked to timber. Aquatic and fishing offences followed with 127 cases, while non-wood forest product (NWFP) violations stood at 42. Land-related offences were 35, timber misuse 24, poaching 20, and forest-fire offences 13.

The 2024 pattern mirrors trends seen since 2020: timber, fisheries, and NWFPs account for most offences, while poaching incidents, though fewer in number, carry far greater ecological risks.

Declines were recorded across nearly all categories. Illegal timber cases dropped 24 percent (640 in 2023 to 488 in 2024). Aquatic and fishing offences fell by 46 percent (234 to 127), and NWFP violations plunged 86 percent (306 to 42). Poaching detections decreased from 29 to 20, while land-related offences dipped from 44 to 35. Timber misuse held steady at 24 cases, and forest-fire offences eased slightly from 18 to 13. ed Nu 20.96 million, about 12 percent less than the Nu 23.80 million collected in 2023. Illegal timber alone accounted for Nu 15.60 million-nearly three-quarters of all fines. Other major contributions came from timber misuse (Nu 1.38M), NWFP offences (Nu 1.24M), aquatic and fishing offences (Nu 1.18M), land-related offences (Nu 0.93M), poaching (Nu 0.45M), and forest-fire violations (Nu 0.18M).

Over the five-year period 2020-2024, fines credited to government revenue reached about Nu 117.3 million, with illegal timber consistently dominating collections.

Poaching, though numerically small, remains ecologically damaging. Species targeted in 2024 included the tiger (Panthera tigris tigris), sambar (Rusa unicolor), Himalayan black bear (Ursus thibetanus), wild pig (Sus scrofa), hornet (Vespa mandarinia), monal pheasant (Lophophorus impejanus), leopard (Panthera pardus), and serow (Capricornis crispus). Offenders were implicated across 15 dzongkhags, with the highest detections in Chhukha, followed by Mongar and Wangdue Phodrang.

Bhutan's wildlife crime profile echoes global patterns. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime's World Wildlife Crime Report 2024 highlights that between 2015 and 2021, seizure records implicated about 4,000 species-3,250 of them listed under CITES-across 162 countries. In that period, authorities intercepted an estimated 13 million individual items and over 16,000 tonnes of contraband.

The report notes that the trade feeds diverse sectors, from food and medicine to live animal and luxury markets, and that actual trafficking far exceeds recorded seizures. Timber and fisheries are flagged worldwide as areas with the largest evidence gaps-mirroring Bhutan's own data.

Domestically, the Department of Forests and Park Services (DoFPS) has rolled out multiple measures to strengthen detection and prosecution. SMART patrolling has been in use since March 2020, with the latest v6 model deployed in July 2025. SMART Connect, enabling real-time patrol tracking, will roll out nationally from late September.

The department is also investing in drone and AI-enabled surveillance, forensic evidence capacity, and frontline training in investigation and legal documentation. Inter-agency coordination through the National Wildlife Crime Control Committee-linking the Royal Bhutan Police, Customs, the Office of the Attorney General, the Judiciary, the Royal Bhutan Army, and the Legal Service Division-has focused on joint operations, intelligence sharing, and plugging procedural gaps.

Community involvement remains critical. DoFPS plans to expand Quick Response Teams, revive informant reward systems in hotspot gewogs, and partner with conservation organisations to raise awareness in vulnerable areas.

All these efforts feed into the National Zero Poaching Strategy 2025-2029. Though launched just two months ago, groundwork is already underway, with most programmes funded from the 2025-2026 fiscal year.

urn:contentItem:6GKD-DXD3-RRXD-C536-00000-00Over 400,000 hectares burned in Spain amid worst wave of wildfires in decades2025-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisNEWSOver 400,000 hectares burned in Spain amid worst wave of wildfires in decadesSPAIN WILDFIRESABSTRACT

Madrid, Aug 25 (EFE).- Over 400,000 hectares have been burned in Spain in 2025, in the worst wave of fires recorded in the country this century, according to the latest data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

FULL TEXT

Madrid, Aug 25 (EFE).- Over 400,000 hectares have been burned in Spain in 2025, in the worst wave of fires recorded in the country this century, according to the latest data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).

At least 252 forest fires have been recorded in large areas of Spain this year, particularly in the north and west of the country.

These figures show that the area destroyed by fire in 2025 far exceeds the more than 42,000 hectares burned in 2024 in 219 fires.

There has also been an increase in Large Forest Fires (LFFs), which are defined as incidents where more than 500 hectares are burned.

The area burned in 2025 is also greater than that burned in 2023 (over 91,000 hectares in 371 fires) and exceeds the figures recorded in 2022, which until now was considered the worst year in terms of area burned by forest fires in the country: more than 300,000 hectares in 493 fires.

According to Civil Protection, 14 forest fires remained active on Monday, mainly in the province of León. EFE

urn:contentItem:6GRF-51B3-RY5S-21G3-00000-00Midagri inaugurates Observatory of Forest Heritage and Wildlife2025-09-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisMidagri inaugurates Observatory of Forest Heritage and Wildlife

Holder of Midagri indicated that this observatory will be a necessary tool to promote forest plantationsThe Minister of Agrarian Development and Irrigation, Angel Manero inaugurated the Observatory of Forest Heritage and Wildlife, which has high -resolution satellite images, remote sensors and artificial intelligence, which will allow generating early alerts and reports in almost real time on threats to the natural heritage.

From the headquarters of the National Forest and Wildlife Service (Serfor), attached to the agriculture, the minister said that it is a platform that seeks to strengthen the integral management of forest heritage, promoting the sustainable and productive management of natural resources nationwide.

The implementation of this Observatory will be an important and necessary tool to promote forest plantations. This will allow us to identify these potential areas (plantations) where we must develop thoroughly, said the minister.

In addition, he said that the Government through Midagri will continue to drive the forestry sector. We are going to enter this year to do everything necessary so that the next one already begins to walk and to July 2026 to have this completely aimed, structured and the new government simply continue with the actions, he said.

The implementation of the Observatory of Forest and Wildlife Heritage will contribute directly to the reduction of deforestation, forest fire prevention and biodiversity conservation, consolidating the States commitment to sustainable development.

The information generated by the Observatory constitutes a strategic input that will contribute to decision -making, policy formulation and the implementation of prevention, surveillance, control and forest management actions nationwide,

In addition, it improves the response capacity to forest and environmental emergencies, it enables a comprehensive analysis that covers various factors and threats, and reinforces coordination between public entities and actors linked to forest management and risk.

This infrastructure is complemented by the Forest Heritage Impact Monitoring Satellite Platform (SAMI), which will provide online access to updated information, and with the mobile application alert forest fire, which will allow the settlers to report events directly from their territories.

We are advancing in concrete measures and will benefit mainly small agrarian producers, forest producers, to the communities of the areas and to all the populations that are linked to all these projects, said the minister.

Midagri argued that the operation of the Observatory will also allow analyzing, systematizing and disseminating strategic information aimed at detecting, preventing and minimizing the main threats to forest heritage, such as deforestation, the risks associated with forest fires and non -authorized land use changes, as well as the monitoring of forest plantations.

Ministry of Agrarian Development and Irrigation

urn:contentItem:6GMG-RPF3-SDMY-3447-00000-00York Region to host festival in honour of National Forest Week2025-08-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSYork Region to host festival in honour of National Forest WeekDavid Yin, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterMarkham Review

York Region will kick off National Forest Week with a family-friendly festival at Hollidge Tract Accessible Trail in Stouffville on Sept. 20, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The celebration leads into National Forest Week, which takes place from Sept. 21 to 27.

The free, all-ages festival will feature guided hikes, tours of the Bill Fisch Forest Stewardship and Education Centre, wagon rides, arts and crafts, face painting, and a free Beaver Tail for every attendee.

Kyle Heeley, regional greening coordinator at York Region, explained a few benefits of preserving local forests. He said that forests filter the Earth’s air and water, reduce extreme weather events – such as flooding, and help people exercise their physical and mental health.

“Our forest – the regional forest – has been around for 100 years, and we just want to continue to protect that for future generations as well,” he said.

Residents can take part in other activities to honour National Forest Week. Heeley listed tree planting, hiking, bird watching, and bike riding as potential options.

Additionally, the Canadian Institute of Forestry provides free toolkits on its website, which include a list of activities for all ages.

National Forest Week was established around 1920 as Forest Fire Prevention Week. At the time, the biggest threat to forests was manmade forest fires.

Forest Fire Prevention Week was later renamed to National Forest Week in 1967 to better represent a broader range of forest preservation issues.

For more event details, including location and parking options, visit york.ca/ForestEvents

urn:contentItem:6GF5-9FF3-RS57-90RH-00000-00President Prabowo Subianto Leads Cabinet Meeting on Forest Fire Mitigation from Hambalang Residence2025-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisPresident Prabowo Subianto Leads Cabinet Meeting on Forest Fire Mitigation from Hambalang Residence

03 Aug 2025 (Cabinet Secretariat of the Republic of Indonesia) President Prabowo Subianto led a Cabinet Meeting via video conference from his residence in Hambalang in Bogor regency over the weekend.

The primary agenda was to monitor the potential forest and land fires and to implement appropriate mitigation measures.

In his written statement, Cabinet Secretary Teddy Indra Wijaya explained that President Prabowo Subianto expressed his appreciation to the Ministries and all teams involved in the mitigation efforts.

'The President expressed his appreciation to Ministry of the Environment and other relevant ministries, as well as the teams, for their efforts in preventing and mitigating potential forest fires across the country,' wrote the Cabinet Secretary.

Teddy also mentioned that the President highlighted the area affected by fires, noting that it has decreased significantly over the past two years.

'According to the data, there has been a reduction in the area affected by fires. Compared to 2023, the fire-affected area decreased significantly by 33.3%, reaching 376,805 hectares in 2024. Furthermore, data from August 2025 indicates that the total fire-affected area dropped to just 8,95 hectares,' said the Cabinet Secretary.

Teddy added that President Prabowo Subianto also stressed the importance of law enforcement against anyone responsible for land and forest burning, while urging all parties to remain vigilant and prepared for the challenges posed by the upcoming dry season.

'Law enforcement will be strictly applied to anyone responsible for land and forest burning. The President also reminded the teams at both the central and the regional levels of government to stay prepared. According to data from the Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency (MCGA), the dry season is expected to continue until August 2025,' said the Cabinet Secretary.

For the record, the meeting was part of the Government's initiative to ensure that mitigation measures are implemented effectively amid the challenges posed by climate change and extreme weather, which may increase the risk of land and forest fires in certain regions of Indonesia.

urn:contentItem:6GR8-PR53-RSFY-V1KJ-00000-00Across eight Amazon countries, forests on Indigenous lands reduce spread of 27 diseases - Peer-reviewed study2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisAcross eight Amazon countries, forests on Indigenous lands reduce spread of 27 diseases - Peer-reviewed study

Switzerland: International Union for Conservation of Nature has issued the following press release:

The first study of its kind, led by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), gathered data from 1,733 municipalities representing more than 74% of the Amazon to find that forests on Indigenous lands are a prophylactic for diseases threatening the region ’ s 33 million people. Findings add to mounting evidence that recognising and enforcing Indigenous Peoples ’ land rights has widespread benefits – for the climate, nature and, now, health.

New research published today in Communications Earth and Environment, a Nature Group journal, finds that municipalities in the Amazon region closest to healthy forests on Indigenous lands face less risk from rising cases of two categories of disease: cardiovascular and respiratory diseases due to forest fires and illnesses spread when humans come into closer contact with animals and insects.

The findings, released at the onset of forest fire season in the region and in advance of the climate negotiations (COP30) in Belém, Brazil, is the latest study in a growing body of evidence showing that Indigenous land rights are critical to tackling climate change, biodiversity loss and disease spread that, in the case of forest fires, create immediate and widespread health hazards.

“Indigenous forests in the Amazon bring health benefits to millions,” said Paula Prist, Senior Programme Coordinator of the Forests and Grasslands Programme of the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).“We have long known that the rainforest is home to medicinal plants and animals that have cured countless illnesses. This study offers new evidence that forests themselves are a balm for fire-related threats to people ’ s lungs and hearts, to illnesses like Chagas, malaria and spotted fevers. Ensuring Indigenous communities have strong rights over their lands is the best way to keep forests and their health benefits intact. ”

Researchers examined 20 years of data on 27 health issues – 21 fire-related and six zoonotic (spread from animals to people) or vector-borne (spread from insects to people) diseases – across eight Amazonian countries: Bolivia, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Suriname, Venezuela and French Guiana. The study “Indigenous territories can safeguard human health depending on the landscape structure and legal status” revealed that lands managed by Indigenous Peoples consistently decrease disease incidence.

“The study comes just as forest fire season arrives in Amazon countries,” said Ana Filipa Palmeirim, visiting professor, Federal University of Pará and co-first author of the study. “These fires fill the air with thick, choking smoke, sending droves to the hospital for respiratory ailments. As daily life comes to a complete standstill, children and the elderly must stay home to avoid hospital visits. Even when fires take place in remote forest areas, winds spread the pollution far and wide, creating deadly public health emergencies. ”

Between 2001 and 2019, almost 30,000,000 cases of fire-related, zoonotic and vector-borne diseases were reported in the Amazon rainforest. Illnesses studied include Chagas disease, malaria, hantavirus, visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis and spotted fevers. Studies have shown that deforestation is directly linked to a rise in these so-called neglected tropical diseases, which don ’ t have readily available cures. Across the region, deforestation is increasing due to aggressive agriculture expansion, oil drilling and large infrastructure projects like roads and hydropower plants.

Intentionally set forest fires have emerged as a particularly significant threat to the Amazon region and the people living there. Many fires are started by illegal actors who cut down forests without permission to do so, then burn the remaining vegetation to make room for cattle grazing or crops. Climate change impacts – such as high temperatures and decreased rainfall – increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires and the area burned.

Exposure to these fires leads to increased respiratory symptoms, heart disease, stroke, emphysema and lung cancer, as well as bronchitis, asthma, chest pain, chronic lung and heart problems. In the Amazon, forest fire smoke is directly linked to an increase in hospitalisations for these ailments. In the Brazilian Amazon alone, between 2002 and 2011, the fires were responsible for, on average, 2,906 premature deaths from cardiopulmonary disease and lung cancer.

The study released today builds on recent research findings that the Indigenous forests in the Brazilian Amazon can potentially prevent about 15 million cases of respiratory and cardiovascular infections each year by soaking up pollutants emitted by forest fires.

urn:contentItem:6GKK-VWP3-RVD9-D0T5-00000-00Beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitors2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitorsANDREW FORGRAVE

A POPULAR beach was locked down for a second successive weekend after fire broke out in adjacent woodland.

Visitors already at the site were asked to give firefighters "space to work" while they tackled the blaze.

Nearby residents could smell smoke from the fire in Newborough Forest, which borders the beach of Traeth Llanddwyn.

Illegal wild campers were thought to be to blame and site manager Natural Resources Wales (NRW) slammed their "irresponsible behaviour".

The local community has been living on a knife-edge this summer as tinder-dry conditions brought the risk of a major blaze. Extra patrols were mounted over the Bank Holiday weekend but pleas not to light BBQs and campfires went unheeded.

On Sunday evening local NRW wardens closed the road gates at Newborough Forest, through which visitors must travel to reach the beach. They reported a small fire in the forest had been extinguished but was at risk of reigniting.

Wardens said they shut the site as a precautionary measure to safeguard visitors and the local community. The closure was extended through most of Bank Holiday Monday, when the blaze was found to have restarted.

Just eight days previously, the National Nature Reserve was locked down for first the first time ever following reports wardens had been "overwhelmed" by the number of illegal campers.

During this week's lockdown, visitors reportedly ignored the closure and walked to the beach after parking on the A4080. Scores of cars in the area were ticketed by Anglesey Council enforcement officers.

It wasn't until 9.23pm on Monday night that NRW declared the reserve back open. Visitors were reminded that camping is not permitted and that BBQs are banned in all parts of the reserve.

A spokesperson said: "The vast majority of people visiting this special place do so responsibly. Yet, this weekend, we have unfortunately seen the significant impact irresponsible behaviour can have on this landscape.

"A single spark from a BBQ or campfire can lead to fires that can devastate habitats and wildlife and put people at risk of harm.

"We all have a role to play in minimising the risks of wildfires during this very dry spell. We're asking everyone to follow the rules and help protect what makes this place so special."

Traeth Llandwyn and Newborough Forest have been popularised on social media, with the beach gaining fame as a filming location for HBO's House of the Dragon series. Despite extensive messaging by NRW, problems have escalated at the reserve this summer.

To tackle traffic issues in the nearby village of Newborough, new parking rules were introduced this summer at Traeth Llandwyn's three car parks.

When full - often by 10am at busy times - these are now closed until mid-afternoon. Day-long charges were also hiked to £15.

However locals report that late arrivals just park on surrounding roads and tackle the long walk through the forest to Traeth Llanddwyn. "I see hundreds walking past my home on hot days," said a nearby resident. "About 60% are carrying tents, BBQs and back packs. Its heartbreaking."

Wardens can only ask visitors to remove tents and extinguish fires - often facing abuse when doing so.

NRW hopes a new barrierless parking system due to be introduced this autumn will help control overnight camping.

Some locals are sceptical and want more overnight lockdowns. "Maybe we can sleep a bit better in the evenings knowing that the forest won't go up in flames," said one woman online. Another agreed there was a need for ongoing patrols. She said: "Like many other Anglesey residents, I feel unable to enjoy this beautiful place because of the actions of disrespectful people."

¦ Traffic wardens are cracking down on vehicles parked on A4080 verges at Newborough Forest (Image: Anglesey council)¦ Llanddwyn's car parks were closed for much of Bank Holiday Monday - though some visitors still trekked through the forest to reach the beach (Image: Stephen Llowarch/Wiki)

urn:contentItem:6H69-VV13-S98R-D2PH-00000-00Opinion Doctors, lawyers and priests keep secrets. Why not your chatbot?2025-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisOpinion Doctors, lawyers and priests keep secrets. Why not your chatbot?Nils Gilman | For The New York Times

On New Year's Day, Jonathan Rinderknecht purportedly asked ChatGPT "Are you at fault if a fire is lift because of your cigarettes," misspelling the word "lit." "Yes," ChatGPT replied. Ten months later, he is now being accused of having started a small blaze that authorities say reignited a week later to start the devastating Palisades fire.

Mr. Rinderknecht, who has pleaded not guilty, had previously told the chatbot how "amazing" it had felt to burn a Bible months prior, according to a federal complaint, and had also asked it to create a "dystopian" painting of a crowd of poor people fleeing a forest fire, while a crowd of rich people mocked them behind a gate.

For federal authorities, these interactions with artificial intelligence indicated Mr. Rinderknecht's pyrotechnic state of mind and motive and intent to start the fire. Along with GPS data that they say puts him at the scene of the initial blaze, it was enough to arrest and charge him with several counts, including destruction of property by means of fire.

This disturbing development is a warning for our legal system. As people increasingly turn to A.I. chat tools as confidants, therapists and advisers, we urgently need a new form of legal protection that would safeguard most private communications between people and A.I. chatbots. I call it "A.I. interaction privilege."

All legal privileges rest on the idea that certain relationships - lawyer and client, doctor and patient, priest and penitent - serve a social good that depends on candor. Without assurance of privacy, people self-censor and society loses the benefits of honesty. Courts have historically been reluctant to create new privileges, except where "confidentiality has to be absolutely essential to the functioning of the relationship," Greg Mitchell, a University of Virginia law professor, told me. Many users' engagements with A.I. now reach this threshold.

People speak increasingly freely to A.I. systems, not as diaries but as partners in conversation. That's because these systems hold conversations that are often indistinguishable from human dialogue. The machine seemingly listens, reasons and provides responses - in some cases not just reflecting but shaping how users think and feel. A.I. systems can draw users out, just as a good lawyer or therapist does. Many people turn to A.I. precisely because they lack a safe and affordable human outlet for taboo or vulnerable thoughts.

This is arguably by design. Just last month the OpenAI chief executive, Sam Altman, announced that the next iteration of its ChatGPT platform would "relax" some restrictions on users and allow them to make their ChatGPT "respond in a very humanlike way."

Allowing the government to access such unfiltered exchanges and treat them as legal confessions would have a massive chilling effect. If every private thought experiment can later be weaponized in court, users of A.I. will censor themselves, undermining some of the most valuable uses of these systems. It will destroy the candid relationship that makes A.I. useful for mental health and legal and financial problem-solving, turning a potentially powerful tool for self-discovery and self-representation into a potential legal liability.

At present, most digital interactions fall under the Third-Party Doctrine, which holds that information voluntarily disclosed to other parties - or stored on a company's servers - carries "no legitimate expectation of privacy." This doctrine allows government access to much online behavior (such as Google search histories) without a warrant.

But are A.I. conversations "voluntary disclosures" in this sense? Since many users approach these systems not as search engines but as private counselors, the legal standard should evolve to reflect that expectation of discretion. A.I. companies already hold more intimate data than any therapist or lawyer ever could. Yet they have no clear legal duty to protect it.

A.I. interaction privilege should mirror existing legal privileges in three respects. First, communications with the A.I. for the purpose of seeking counsel or emotional processing should be protected from forced disclosure in court. Users could designate protected sessions through app settings or claim privilege during legal discovery if the context of the conversation supports it. Second, this privilege must incorporate the so-called duty to warn principle, which obliges therapists to report imminent threats of harm. If an A.I. service reasonably believes a user poses an immediate danger to self or others or has already caused harm, disclosure should be not just permitted, but obligated. And third, there must be an exception for crime and fraud. If A.I. is used to plan or execute a crime, it should be discoverable under judicial oversight.

Under this logic, Mr. Rinderknecht's case reveals both the need and the limits of such protection. His cigarette query, functionally equivalent to an internet search, would not merit privilege. But under A.I. interaction privilege, his confession about Bible burning should be protected. It was neither a plan for a crime nor an imminent threat.

Creating a new privilege follows the law's pattern of adapting to new forms of trust. The psychotherapist-patient privilege itself was only formally recognized in 1996, when the Supreme Court acknowledged the therapeutic value of confidentiality. The same logic applies to A.I. now The social benefit of candid interaction outweighs the cost of occasional lost evidence.

To leave these conversations legally unprotected is to invite a regime where citizens must fear that their digital introspection could someday be used against them. Private thought - whether spoken to a lawyer, a therapist or a machine - must remain free from the fear of state intrusion.

Nils Gilman is senior adviser to the Berggruen Institute and a co-author of "Children of a Modest Star Planetary Thinking for an Age of Crises." This article originally appeared in The New York Times.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VNV3-RS2V-23MF-00000-00Chilean helicopter joins firefighting effort in Bolivia2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisChilean helicopter joins firefighting effort in Bolivia


The forest fires in the San Matías and Noel Kempff Mercado Integrated Management Natural Area (ANMI) parks, located in the department of Santa Cruz, were controlled, according to information provided by the national government on Friday. The Vice Minister of Civil Defense, Juan Carlos Calvimontes, announced the arrival of a helicopter from Chile that will join the efforts to fight the forest fires, in addition to supporting the surveillance tasks in the region.


Currently, the only active fire is reported in the municipality of Concepción. Calvimontes informed that "a helicopter arrived from the sister Republic of Chile. It is going to help with the task of suffocation". This aircraft will remain in San Ignacio de Velasco to reinforce the control of the Noel Kempff Mercado Park. Thanks to the coordinated work with the Forest Fire Battalion, the hot spots in San Matías and Noel Kempff were already neutralized.
However, the vice minister warned that intensive surveillance will be maintained for 48 hours. "The forest fires in the San Matías ANMI park are already completely controlled. We are going to monitor for 48 hours to see if there is any reactivation," Calvimontes indicated.
Aerial and logistical support
In relation to the Noel Kempff Mercado park, Calvimontes explained that the first support of two helicopters that are operating in the area of the Caparuch mountain range has already been received. "Yesterday they were able to put out the fire in the Noel Kempff Mercado Park," said the vice minister.
The helicopter from Chile will be under the direct command of the Bolivian team that is in San Ignacio and will have the necessary logistical support. It was also announced the transfer of a tanker with more than 15,000 liters of fuel to the area, which will guarantee aerial operations.
International aid and agreements
Calvimontes mentioned that the international aid is materialized through an agreement with the Airbus Foundation, managed by the government of France. "This first part is part of the help that the French government is giving us (...), if it is necessary to complete more flight hours, this will become part of the resources of the National General Treasury", detailed the vice minister.
In this context, he stated that currently the only active forest fire is in Concepción. "At this moment the only officially reported fire is the one in Concepción", said Calvimontes.
Rains help to contain fires
The rains recorded in recent hours have helped contain the fires. "Yesterday it rained quite a lot in the Chiquitania area, especially in the sector of Roboré, Carmen Rivero Torres, San Matías and part of San Ignacio de Velasco," pointed out the vice minister.
/KMMN
The post Helicopter from Chile joins firefighting efforts in Bolivia first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9WM3-RY9B-V38K-00000-00Warning from the Guardia Civil to all of Spain: from now on, it asks the population not to do this because it could affect the whole country.2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisWarning from the Guardia Civil to all of Spain: from now on, it asks the population not to do this because it could affect the whole country.


The Civil Guard of the A Coruña Command has proposed for sanction three people for failing to comply with safety restrictions at a time of maximum alert for risk of forest fire.


In depth
Two of them were residents of Santiago de Compostela who were having a barbecue in Muxía and the third, a resident of Irixoa who was burning stubble on a private property. The economic amount of these infractions ranges between 1,001 and 1,000,000 euros.
According to the Armed Forces, the first of the facts occurred when a patrol, which was carrying out a preventive service of public safety, observed a column of smoke in the vicinity of the praia dos Muíños, in the town of Muxía, A Coruña. When they went to the point, they located two people who were having a barbecue.
More details
The second event occurred after receiving a telephone alert, which reported the existence of a forest fire in the place of Ambroa, in the municipality of Irixoa in A Coruña, about 100 meters from homes. A patrol of the Curtis Post, moved to the place, verified that it was the burning of stubble on a private farm.
In both cases, the Civil Guard proceeded to the identification of those responsible and the preparation of the corresponding report for alleged serious infringement of Law 7/2012 of Forestry of Galicia, forcing them to extinguish the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GYP-T9F3-RV32-J0RD-00000-00Researchers from Institute of Information Discuss Research in Information and Data Tagging (An Adaptive Steganographic Method for Reversible Information Embedding in X-Ray Images)2025-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisINFORMATION TECHNOLOGY - INFORMATION AND DATA TAGGINGResearchers from Institute of Information Discuss Research in Information and Data Tagging (An Adaptive Steganographic Method for Reversible Information Embedding in X-Ray Images)


2025 OCT 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Information Technology Daily -- Research findings on information and data tagging are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Almaty, Kazakhstan, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The rapid digitalisation of the medical field has heightened concerns over protecting patients' personal information during the transmission of medical images."


The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Institute of Information: "This study introduces a method for securely transmitting X-ray images that contain embedded patient data. The proposed steganographic approach ensures that the original image remains intact while the embedded data is securely hidden, a critical requirement in medical contexts. To guarantee reversibility, the Interpolation Near Pixels method was utilised, recognised as one of the most effective techniques within reversible data hiding (RDH) frameworks. Additionally, the method integrates a statistical property preservation technique, enhancing the scheme's alignment with ideal steganographic characteristics. Specifically, the 'forest fire' algorithm partitions the image into interconnected regions, where statistical analyses of low-order bits are performed, followed by arithmetic decoding to achieve a desired distribution. This process successfully maintains the original statistical features of the image."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The effectiveness of the proposed method was validated through stegoanalysis on real-world medical images from previous studies. The results revealed high robustness, with minimal distortion of stegocontainers, as evidenced by high PSNR values ranging between 52 and 81 dB."
For more information on this research see: An Adaptive Steganographic Method for Reversible Information Embedding in X-Ray Images. Computers, 2025,14(9):386. (Computers - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/computers). The publisher for Computers is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/computers14090386.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Elmira Daiyrbayeva, Institute of Information and Computational Technologies of the Committee of Science of the Ministry of Science and Higher Education of the Republic of Kazakhstan, Almaty 050010, Kazakhstan. Additional authors for this research include Aigerim Yerimbetova, Ekaterina Merzlyakova, Ualikhan Sadyk, Aizada Sarina, Zhamilya Taichik, Irina Ismailova, Yerbolat Iztleuov, Asset Nurmangaliyev.
Keywords for this news article include: Institute of Information, Almaty, Kazakhstan, Asia, Information Technology, Information and Data Tagging.

urn:contentItem:6GKX-48B3-RSWK-X0D6-00000-00Research Conducted at Yunnan University Has Provided New Information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Dmpnet: a Lightweight Remote Sensing Forest Wildfire Detection Network Based On Multi-scale Heterogeneous Attention Mechanism and Dynamic ...)2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisAVIATION - UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLEResearch Conducted at Yunnan University Has Provided New Information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Dmpnet: a Lightweight Remote Sensing Forest Wildfire Detection Network Based On Multi-scale Heterogeneous Attention Mechanism and Dynamic ...)


2025 AUG 28 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- A new study on Aviation - Unmanned Aerial Vehicle is now available. According to news reporting originating from Kunming, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV)-based remote sensing technology has emerged as a critical tool for forest fire detection. However, existing methods face significant challenges in simultaneously achieving high detection accuracy and real-time performance, particularly in scenarios characterized by multi-scale variations, non-stationary behaviors, and complex occlusions."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Yunnan University, "To address these issues, we propose DMPNet, a lightweight neural network specifically designed for forest fire detection. Unlike conventional approaches that sacrifice accuracy for parameter reduction, DMPNet employs an optimized feature extraction architecture (PCSPNet), which not only preserves robust feature representation but also reduces the number of parameters by 16.67% (approximately 500K) compared to YOLOv8n. Furthermore, the dynamic fusion scaling strategy (DSFNet) is integrated into the network's neck to dynamically adjust the size and weight of feature maps, overcoming the limitations of static fusion. Additionally, DMPNet incorporates a multi-scale heterogeneous attention mechanism (MSHA), which effectively addresses occlusion issues through multi-scale contextual reasoning and cross-scale feature interactions. Experimental results demonstrate that DMPNet achieves an inference speed of 1.2 ms, with mAP50 reaching 86.8% and mAP@50-95 at 59%. When compared to YOLOv10n under similar parameter constraints, DMPNet improves mAP50 by 4.2% and surpasses MobileNet, GhostNet, and EfficientNet by over 20% in accuracy."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "By balancing model compactness, precision, and efficiency, DMPNet provides a robust solution for real-time forest fire monitoring."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Dmpnet: a Lightweight Remote Sensing Forest Wildfire Detection Network Based On Multi-scale Heterogeneous Attention Mechanism and Dynamic Scaling Fusion Strategy. Digital Signal Processing, 2025;164. Digital Signal Processing can be contacted at: Academic Press Inc Elsevier Science, 525 B St, Ste 1900, San Diego, CA 92101-4495, USA. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Digital Signal Processing - www.journals.elsevier.com/digital-signal-processing/)
The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Hongwei Ding, Yunnan University, College of Information Technology, Kunming, Yunnan Province, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Yingping Long, Bo Li, Yuanjing Zhu and Zhijun Yang.

urn:contentItem:6FCR-94H3-RST3-D3SJ-00000-00Community-based forest fire management2025-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisCommunity-based forest fire managementSentinel Digital Desk

Incidents of massive forest fires almost simultaneously in different parts of Assam have put the state's disaster response system to the test. The situation has set off the alarm bell for enhancing mitigation capabilities to prevent catastrophic forest fires in the state. Rising temperature on account of climate change impact and prolonged dry spells increases forest fire risk and vulnerability. Real-time risk assessment is crucial for improving disaster response.

As forest fire hotspots are spread across the state, with some of these in far and remote areas, mobilising logistics before the fire spreads and engulfs a larger area is easier said than done. Application of satellite technology has significantly improved dissemination of forest fire alerts to disaster management authorities to act without losing much time. Dashboards showing updated information on inventory readiness for firefighting in all firefighting stations located nearest to known forest hotspots and vulnerable locations can help state and national disaster management authorities to identify critical gaps and initiate measures to bridge those. Mobilising firefighting equipment, materials and trained personnel to deal with fire emergencies in human settlements and forest areas requires different strategies. However, the expansion of human settlements closer to forest areas has increased the vulnerability of forest fires engulfing adjacent dwelling houses, public buildings, etc. in the state. Containing and dousing forest fires, therefore, needs to be much quicker to prevent loss of life and properties. While prevention and detection remain the top priorities, the readiness for emergency response to an outbreak of forest fire needs focused attention on planning, building capacity and adding to the inventory of firefighting equipment. The National Action Plan on Forest Fire launched in 2018 lays emphasis on informing, empowering and enabling the forest fringe communities to work with the state forest department to enhance forest fire management capabilities. The availability of water sources nearer to forest fire spots is a strategic advantage for aerial firefighting, such as the Bambi bucket used by Indian Air Force helicopters for collecting water from a natural or manmade water reservoir and pouring it over forest fires. Deployment of IAF Bambi buckets helped douse blazing forest fires in Dzukou Valley along Manipur-Nagaland and during forest fires in Mizoram. Community-Based Disaster Preparedness (CBDP) is the hallmark of new-age disaster risk management. The Assam Disaster Management Plan 2022, prepared and released by the Assam State Disaster Management Authority, lists different components of CBDP, which include the formation of ward and village-level disaster management committees, documenting past disasters with the help of the elderly population and analysing those with the help of domain experts, communities developing a seasonality calendar of disasters based on past disaster events and mapping of risk and vulnerabilities by the communities themselves. Application of the CBDP approach in forest fire management will be effective only when it is backed by a modern firefighting support system. Loss of forest cover due to indiscriminate tree felling for infrastructure projects and also due to encroachment and illegal settlement of people in forest areas, as well as the felling of trees by timber smugglers, have precipitated the problem of rapid loss of moisture and increased forest fire risk during the fire season. Eviction of encroachment from forest areas does not immediately lead to restoration. Therefore, preventing forest encroachment also needs to be prioritised as part of CBDP by mobilising the community to remain vigilant and report any such illegal activity to forest authorities. Erratic rainfall and long dry spells have compounded the problem of soil moisture reduction and increasing the forest fire risk. Incentivising forest fringe dwellers to raise agroforestry is a pragmatic approach to increase soil moisture in deforested zones. Joint Forest Management Committees (JFMC) can play a crucial role in forest fire management and restoration of lost forest cover. The onus is on the Forest Department to take the initiative in forming and incentivising JFMCs to take a proactive role in forest fire risk mitigation and post-disaster eco-restoration by recognising their role as equal stakeholders. Participation of JFMC members in Forest Department-led initiatives for forest fire risk mitigation should not be limited to ritualistic and event-based participation. Involvement of JFMCs in the planning process through a consultative approach will facilitate a broader role of communities as protectors of forests. The usual approach of the Forest Department of enforcing a restrictive regime for forest fringe communities is a barrier to proactive participation in forest conservation. Developing JFMCs as strong community institutions through awareness, sharing of traditional knowledge of communities for forest and nature conservation, and knowledge and expertise of the department for scientific measures to address conservation issues will go a long way in addressing challenges of forest cover loss apart from reducing vulnerability, risk mitigation and better response to outbreaks of forest fires. Areas under Assam's boundaries with neighbouring states having large stretches of forest, interstate coordination is also essential to improve forest fire management in the state and the region.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G1B3-RS1P-J3D7-00000-00After fire, 350 hectares reported affected in Parque Tunari2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisAfter fire, 350 hectares reported affected in Parque Tunari


After the suffocation of the forest fire in the Tunari Park, in Cochabamba, the departmental coordinator of Civil Defense, Samuel Pereira, reported this Friday that 350 hectares were affected.


The official informed that the fire is completely extinguished and that in the work 28,000 liters of water were discharged in areas of difficult access.
"We do not know who is responsible because there are more than 350 hectares," Pereira declared on Bolivia TV.
In addition, he regretted that while cooling works were being carried out, another fire was activated in the Tambo area, in Quillacollo, which suggests intentionality.
"It would seem to be premeditated, one fire is extinguished and another one is ignited", he warned.
The official explained that to date Cochabamba recorded 33 forest fires and said that Civil Defense has the names of possible perpetrators of some events.
"If the responsibility were ours, we would denounce, but it is not up to us to prosecute. It is time for the law to be enforced," he emphasized.
The forest fire in the Tunari Park started on Tuesday and firefighters and national, departmental and municipal units were involved in putting it out.
The Bambi Bucket helicopter was also used and discharged more than 28,000 liters of water.
Tunari National Park will remain under surveillance. It is considered a strategic area due to its ecological value and its role in water supply.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-PS63-RS7W-K41F-00000-00IDB approves $21 million loan for forest conservation and restoration in Honduras2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:55ZLexisNexisIDB approves $21 million loan for forest conservation and restoration in Honduras


The Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) has approved a loan of US$25 million (21 million euros) to contribute to forest conservation and restoration in Honduras, the agency said in a statement.


The financing includes 15 million dollars (12 million euros) from regular ordinary capital and another 10 million dollars (8 million euros) on concessional terms.
This loan contemplates repayment periods of 25 and 40 years, respectively, plus a grace period of 5.5 years, and will benefit more than 4,800 people in the departments of Atlántida, Colón, Yoro, Olancho and El Paraíso.
Planned actions include technical assistance, delivery of technological packages, restoration of micro-watersheds, implementation of business plans and entrepreneurship, modernization of the forest registration and monitoring system, and strengthening forest fire prevention and risk management.
The 'Sustainable and Resilient Agroforests' project, approved by the IDB's executive board, seeks to promote the adoption of forestry and agroforestry practices that increase forest cover, in addition to promoting income diversification and strengthening the institutional capacity of the National Institute for Forest Conservation and Development, Protected Areas and Wildlife (ICF).

urn:contentItem:6G9T-7V93-RRR8-638D-00000-00Research from Northeast Forestry University Provide New Insights into Forestry (Innovative Approaches to Forest Fire Prevention: Integrating Technology and Ecological Strategies. A Comprehensive Review)2025-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - FORESTRYResearch from Northeast Forestry University Provide New Insights into Forestry (Innovative Approaches to Forest Fire Prevention: Integrating Technology and Ecological Strategies. A Comprehensive Review)


2025 JUL 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on forestry. According to news reporting originating from Harbin, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The problems associated with the advancement of technology and the environment are growing more complicated in recent years."


The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Northeast Forestry University: "Wildfires are one of the most important environmental challenges since they seriously endanger the world's ecosystems. There are many different types of damage done to forests, which result in both climate change and the devastation of terrestrial ecosystems. Consequently, the implementation of efficient strategies for early warning, prevention, the efficacy of ecological methods like fuel management strategies and green fire barriers in preventing wildfires and well-coordinated treatments is necessary to lessen their impact on both people and the environment. This overview examines the development of several technologies from previous years to the present with the purpose of detecting, tracking, and preventing forest fires. It draws attention to the advantages, restrictions, and potential advancements in this field of research. Because of their catastrophic effects on ecosystems and potential consequences on the climate, forest fires have become a major environmental concern."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "To create more potent plans for preventing and controlling wildfires, our research demonstrated the necessity for significant advancements in ecological methods, technological breakthroughs, and community involvement to strengthen wildfire preservation efforts."
For more information on this research see: Innovative Approaches to Forest Fire Prevention: Integrating Technology and Ecological Strategies. A Comprehensive Review. South-East European Forestry, 2025,16(1):95-113. (South-East European Forestry - http://www.seefor.eu/). The publisher for South-East European Forestry is Croatian Forest Research Institute.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.15177/seefor.25-04.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Syed Shaheer Hassan, Northeast Forestry University, School of Forestry, Heilongjiang Province State Key Laboratory of Forest Protection, Xiang Fang District, CH-150040 Harbin, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Guang Yang, Sana Tahir, Haseeb Ahmad, Muhammad Sabir, Laila Noor, Khuzin Dinislam.
Keywords for this news article include: Northeast Forestry University, Harbin, People's Republic of China, Asia, Agriculture, Ecology, Forestry, Technology.
