urn:contentItem:6GKK-19Y3-RV1G-84MS-00000-00Famous beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitors2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisTOPIC -ANGLESEYVersion:1Famous beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitorsBy, Andrew Forgrave

The area was closed for much of Bank Holiday Monday on one of warmest days of the year

A popular beach was locked down for a second successive weekend after fire broke out in adjacent woodland. Visitors already at the site were asked to give firefighters "space to work" while they tackled the blaze.

Nearby residents could smell smoke from the fire in Newborough Forest, which borders the beach of Traeth Llanddwyn. Illegal wild campers were thought to be to blame and site manager Natural Resources Wales NRW slammed their "irresponsible behaviour".

The local community has been living on a knife-edge this summer as tinder-dry conditions brought the risk of a major blaze. Extra patrols were mounted over the Bank Holiday weekend but pleas not to light BBQs and campfires went unheeded.

On Sunday evening, August 24, local NRW wardens closed the road gates at Newborough Forest, through which visitors must travel to reach the beach. They reported a small fire in the forest had been extinguished but was at risk of reigniting.

Wardens said they shut the site as a precautionary measure to safeguard visitors and the local community. The closure was extended through most of Bank Holiday Monday when the blaze was found to have restarted.

Just eight days previously, the National Nature Reserve was locked down for first the first time ever following reports wardens had been "overwhelmed" by the number of illegal campers.

During yesterday's lockdown, visitors reportedly ignored the closure and walked to the beach after parking on the A4080. Scores of cars in the area were ticketed by Anglesey Council enforcement officers. Sign up now for the latest news on the North Wales Live Whatsapp community

It wasn't until 9.23pm last night that NRW declared the reserve back open. Visitors were reminded that camping is not permitted and that BBQs are banned in all parts of the reserve.

A spokesperson said: "The vast majority of people visiting this special place do so responsibly. Yet, this weekend, we have unfortunately seen the significant impact irresponsible behaviour can have on this landscape.

"A single spark from a BBQ or campfire can lead to fires that can devastate habitats and wildlife, and put people at risk of harm. We all have a role to play in minimising the risks of wildfires during this very dry spell. We're asking everyone to follow the rules and help protect what makes this place so special."

Traeth Llandwyn and Newborough Forest have been popularised on social media, with the beach gaining fame as a filming location for HBO's House of the Dragon series. Despite extensive messaging by NRW, problems have escalated at the reserve this summer.

To tackle traffic issues in the nearby village of Newborough, new parking rules were introduced this summer at Traeth Llandwyn's three car parks. When full - often by 10am at busy times - these are now closed until mid-afternoon. Day-long charges were also hiked to £15.

However locals report that late arrivals just park on surrounding roads and tackle the long walk through the forest to Traeth Llanddwyn. "I see hundreds walking past my home on hot days," said a nearby resident. "About 60% are carrying tents, BBQs and back packs. Its heart-breaking."

Wardens can only ask visitors to remove tents and extinguish fires - often facing abuse when doing so. NRW hopes a new barrier less parking system due to be introduced this autumn will help control overnight camping.

Some locals are sceptical and want more overnight lockdowns. "Maybe we can sleep a bit better in the evenings knowing that the forest won't go up in flames," said one woman online. Get the best island stories from our Anglesey newsletter -sent every Friday

Another agreed there was a need for ongoing patrols. She said: "Like many other Anglesey residents, I feel unable to enjoy this beautiful place because of the actions of disrespectful people."

urn:contentItem:6GP7-FPM3-S2WM-242Y-00000-00PEDRO SNCHEZ IS GRATEFUL FOR THE "COMMENDABLE WORK", "EFFORT" AND "COMMITMENT TO THE TERRITORY" OF THE BRIF TO TACKLE THE FIRES2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisPEDRO SNCHEZ IS GRATEFUL FOR THE "COMMENDABLE WORK", "EFFORT" AND "COMMITMENT TO THE TERRITORY" OF THE BRIF TO TACKLE THE FIRESStates News ServiceMADRID, Spain

The following information was released by the President of the Government of Spain:

The President of the Government of Spain has insisted on the need to reach a State Pact to deal with the climate emergency, "leaving aside partisan fighting". "We will strive to ensure that this happens and that we can reach this great agreement between parties, institutions and society as a whole."

On behalf of the Executive and the country as a whole, Pedro Snchez thanked the "commendable work, professionalism, commitment to the territory and the immense effort" of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF) in tackling the fires suffered by our country. "The recognition of the firefighters of the Ministry of Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge and also the applause of Spanish society as a whole for their work throughout these difficult weeks," in which they have had to "work and battle side by side with many other troops from all over Spain," he said.

Speaking to the media after his visit to the base of the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigade in Tabuyo del Monte (Len), the head of the Executive stressed that the deployment of the BRIF has included the mobilisation of the 11 brigades we have throughout the territory, with a total of more than 600 personnel and more than 200 resources. To this must be added the "unprecedented mobilisation of the Government of Spain, the State law enforcement forces and agencies, the Civil Guard, the National Police, the Military Emergency Unit and volunteers." "All the troops of the General State Administration have been made available to work in coordination with the autonomous communities affected by these fires," he recalled.

Snchez stressed that BRIF workers are public servants who "put their lives at risk" and should have "salary dignity" and job "stability", while at the same time it is necessary to "increase the resources and means they have to be able to do their work better and with greater guarantees of safety". This is the guide for the political action of both the Ministry of Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge and the public company Tragsa itself, said the president, who recalled that in 2024 "a very important step was taken with the approval of the basic framework for brigades, forest firefighters and environmental agents", which improves their conditions. "It is now up to the regional governments to do the same for the personnel that are under their jurisdiction and that form part of their administrations," he said.

State Pact to tackle the climate emergency

Pedro Snchez speaks with personnel from the Forest Fire Reinforcement Brigades (BRIF) | Pool Moncloa/Borja Puig de la Bellacasa

During his speech, the president of the Government of Spain insisted on the "need for all administrations, and not just the administrations, to work hand in hand on a State Pact to tackle the climate emergency," which transcends legislatures. In this sense, he recalled that in the last Council of Ministers the Government had approved "a participatory, open, absolutely democratic roadmap", so that experts can contribute their knowledge and proposals, and that by the end of the year we can have a State pact that will allow us to guide our actions in a systematic and systemic way over the coming months and years."

In his opinion, "it is worth making this effort and putting aside everything related to the legitimate and democratic party struggle" to reach this agreement on the climate emergency, as we did in the past with the State Pact against terrorism, or against sex-based violence, because "in the end what we are talking about is the security of our people."

Snchez stressed that the Government's will to reach this State Pact is "absolute". "We are going to strive, as I will personally, to ensure that this happens and that we can reach this great agreement, this great State Pact between parties and institutions, but also the whole of Spanish society, because we need everyone." "We need the primary sector, environmental NGOs, but also urban and rural areas working together against this climate emergency," he concluded.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88P3-RXCR-B2BC-00000-00Detainee arrested for Berlanga fire released but hospitalized in psychiatric hospital2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisDetainee arrested for Berlanga fire released but hospitalized in psychiatric hospital


The Court of Instruction 1 of Ponferrada, on duty, has agreed the provisional release of the 20-year-old arrested this Thursday for the forest fire declared in Berlanga del Bierzo (León), although with the precautionary measure of his internment in the Psychiatric Unit of the Hospital del Bierzo.


As reported by the press office of the High Court of Justice of Castilla y León, the decision was taken after it was not possible to take a statement to the detainee, due to his state of health, and has specified that he is being investigated for a crime of forest fire.
The 20-year-old was arrested by the Civil Guard shortly after the fire broke out in Berlanga del Bierzo, which due to the proximity to the municipality quickly rose to level 2 severity and forced the eviction of the neighbors, although they were able to return to spend the night in their homes.
As reported yesterday by the Subdelegation of León, about 20 minutes after the start of the fire, an environmental agent contacted the Central of the Civil Guard of León and reported that he had seen an individual leaving the area where the fire had apparently started.
With this information, the Civil Guard mobilized the existing patrols in the area, such as the platoon of the Reserve and Security Group (ARS) of the Civil Guard of Zaragoza, deployed in support of the Command of León due to the serious situation caused by the forest fires raging in the province.
Thus, it was this platoon that arrested the young man, who fully coincided with the description given by the environmental agents, and who, in addition, tried to flee in the presence of the patrol.
The work of the firefighting operation, meanwhile, allowed late yesterday to stabilize the fire, which on Friday has dropped to level 1 severity, and it is expected that in the coming hours can be considered controlled.

urn:contentItem:6GKK-19Y3-RV1G-84P2-00000-00Famous beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitors2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisLATEST WALES NEWSVersion:1Famous beach in lockdown with two-day forest fire blamed on 'irresponsible' visitorsBy, Andrew Forgrave

The area was closed for much of Bank Holiday Monday on one of warmest days of the year

A popular beach was locked down for a second successive weekend after fire broke out in adjacent woodland. Visitors already at the site were asked to give firefighters "space to work" while they tackled the blaze.

Nearby residents could smell smoke from the fire in Newborough Forest, which borders the beach of Traeth Llanddwyn. Illegal wild campers were thought to be to blame and site manager Natural Resources Wales NRW slammed their "irresponsible behaviour".

The local community has been living on a knife-edge this summer as tinder-dry conditions brought the risk of a major blaze. Extra patrols were mounted over the Bank Holiday weekend but pleas not to light BBQs and campfires went unheeded.

On Sunday evening, August 24, local NRW wardens closed the road gates at Newborough Forest, through which visitors must travel to reach the beach. They reported a small fire in the forest had been extinguished but was at risk of reigniting.

Wardens said they shut the site as a precautionary measure to safeguard visitors and the local community. The closure was extended through most of Bank Holiday Monday when the blaze was found to have restarted.

Just eight days previously, the National Nature Reserve was locked down for first the first time ever following reports wardens had been "overwhelmed" by the number of illegal campers.

During yesterday's lockdown, visitors reportedly ignored the closure and walked to the beach after parking on the A4080. Scores of cars in the area were ticketed by Anglesey Council enforcement officers. Sign up now for the latest news on the North Wales Live Whatsapp community

It wasn't until 9.23pm last night that NRW declared the reserve back open. Visitors were reminded that camping is not permitted and that BBQs are banned in all parts of the reserve.

A spokesperson said: "The vast majority of people visiting this special place do so responsibly. Yet, this weekend, we have unfortunately seen the significant impact irresponsible behaviour can have on this landscape.

"A single spark from a BBQ or campfire can lead to fires that can devastate habitats and wildlife, and put people at risk of harm. We all have a role to play in minimising the risks of wildfires during this very dry spell. We're asking everyone to follow the rules and help protect what makes this place so special."

Traeth Llandwyn and Newborough Forest have been popularised on social media, with the beach gaining fame as a filming location for HBO's House of the Dragon series. Despite extensive messaging by NRW, problems have escalated at the reserve this summer.

To tackle traffic issues in the nearby village of Newborough, new parking rules were introduced this summer at Traeth Llandwyn's three car parks. When full - often by 10am at busy times - these are now closed until mid-afternoon. Day-long charges were also hiked to £15.

However locals report that late arrivals just park on surrounding roads and tackle the long walk through the forest to Traeth Llanddwyn. "I see hundreds walking past my home on hot days," said a nearby resident. "About 60% are carrying tents, BBQs and back packs. Its heart-breaking."

Wardens can only ask visitors to remove tents and extinguish fires - often facing abuse when doing so. NRW hopes a new barrier less parking system due to be introduced this autumn will help control overnight camping.

Some locals are sceptical and want more overnight lockdowns. "Maybe we can sleep a bit better in the evenings knowing that the forest won't go up in flames," said one woman online. Get the best island stories from our Anglesey newsletter -sent every Friday

Another agreed there was a need for ongoing patrols. She said: "Like many other Anglesey residents, I feel unable to enjoy this beautiful place because of the actions of disrespectful people."

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5SN3-RW5D-X2JY-00000-00Emergency over in Spain after historic wave of fires2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisEmergency over in Spain after historic wave of fires

The end of a devastating episode
This Sunday, Spain ended the emergency that had been in force for several weeks due to a wave of forest fires considered the most serious in recent years.
"This tragic episode in the history of our country of large simultaneous forest fires in 20 days in a very important part of our country, has ended," said the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, at a press conference.


The official clarified that, although the emergency phase was closed, "the forest fire campaign continues and that is why nobody can lower their guard". She explained that the Government will maintain a constant vigilance and that "we continue in this phase of alert and permanent monitoring with all the means of the State at our disposal".
Balance: victims and area devastatedFILE PHOTO. Smoke and fire rise as a fire rages near Verin, Ourense province, Galicia, Spain. August 16, 2025. REUTERS/Nacho Doce
The wave of fires was described by the Executive as "one of the biggest environmental catastrophes" in recent times. It left four people dead and devastated more than 350,000 hectares in just two weeks, according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
At the most critical moment, more than 20 fires were simultaneously active, while when the end of the emergency was announced, only three major fires remained under control.
The most affected areas were concentrated in the western half of the country, mainly in Galicia, Castilla y León and Extremadura, territories that every summer suffer with greater intensity the effects of fire.
You may be interested in: Spain faces worst fires since 1994; more than 400,000 hectares devastated
An unprecedented heat waveGRAFCAN5706. The area affected by the forest fire declared last night in Tenerife is estimated at about 800 hectares in the municipalities of Arafo and Candelaria, in addition to bordering areas in Santa Ursula and La Victoria, in the north of the island. More than 150 ground troops and 13 aerial means are participating in the firefighting efforts. In the image, area of the highlands of Candelaria. EFE/ Ramón De La Rocha
The origin of the tragedy is closely linked to an unprecedented heat wave, which the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) described as "the most intense since records have been kept".
For 16 consecutive days, temperatures of up to 45 ºC were recorded, with an average of 4.6 ºC above normal. The Carlos III Health Institute estimated that more than 1,100 deaths in August can be directly attributed to this episode, almost triple the number of deaths during the 2022 heat wave.
The extreme heat, coupled with the dryness of the terrain, favored the spread of the large fires that devastated both Spain and Portugal.
A historic summer for firesA helicopter works to contain a fire in the Garganta de los Infiernos nature reserve during a second heat wave in Jerte, Spain, July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Isabel Infantes
The 2025 balance sheet places the country in a scenario comparable to the worst years in recent history. According to EFFIS, 402,903 hectares have been burned so far, making this year the third most devastating since records have been kept, surpassed only by 1985 and 1994.
In 1985, 483,843 hectares were lost, while in 1994 the area burned reached 437,602 hectares, a year that was also particularly tragic because of the 31 deaths and 204 injuries that occurred, according to the National Forest Fire Information Coordination Center.
Of the 10 largest fires recorded in Spain, five occurred this August in the province of Ourense, in the northwest of the country, reflecting the magnitude of the crisis.
Portugal also in emergency
The wave of fires was not limited to Spain. The EFFIS reported that 261,863 hectares burned in Portugal, almost triple the average recorded between 2006 and 2024.
This is the worst balance in that country since 2017, when 114 people died and more than 563,000 hectares were burned.
Overall, the Iberian Peninsula has lost more than 400,000 hectares this summer and has eight deaths - four in Spain and four in Portugal - making 2025 a black year for the region.
Political debate after the fires
The crisis also opened a political struggle. From the central government, the Socialists blamed the Popular Party (PP) for denying climate change and neglecting prevention policies in the communities it governs, which were the most affected by the flames.
The conservatives, for their part, accused the Executive of skimping on resources and not deploying sufficient Army resources. However, the Military Emergency Unit (UME) was present in all the major fires.
This exchange of accusations shows that, in addition to the environmental and human impact, the wave of fires has highlighted the political tensions surrounding emergency management and climate policies.
Extinguishing progress and outlook
Recent weather conditions have helped firefighting teams. An increase in humidity and isolated rains, together with a drop in temperatures below 40 ºC, have allowed progress to be made in controlling the fires.
The president of Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco, stated that "conditions are favorable and significant progress is being made in extinguishing the fire".
However, the authorities insist that the risk is still present and that the fight against fires in 2025 is not yet over.

urn:contentItem:6GNJ-82M3-S0B1-D3VM-00000-00Why Nuno's latest move risks restarting the FOREST FIRE2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 72,73Why Nuno's latest move risks restarting the FOREST FIRETOM COLLOMOSSE

AS risk-averse as they come for most of his career, Nuno Espirito Santo has suddenly started behaving like an impulsive gambler who sticks everything on red.

As if calling out Nottingham Forest's transfer policy on the eve of the season was not hazardous enough, now Nuno has decided to leave the most expensive signing in the club's history kicking his heels when they embark on their first European campaign this century.

Daily Mail Sport revealed on Wednesday that Omari Hutchinson, bought for £37.5million from Ipswich last month, was at risk of being cut from Forest's Europa League squad. Never mind the heavy investment - Nuno has determined he will not need the promising attacker for at least the first half of the tournament.

UEFA regulations mean clubs cannot simply register every player on their books and, when the list was published on Wednesday evening, our story was confirmed - Hutchinson had missed out along with Oleksandr Zinchenko, a last-minute loan signing from Arsenal.

We will not hear from Nuno until next week, but he was due to hold talks with Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis before the Premier League resumes on September 13. These decisions will surely be high on the agenda.

WHY WERE HUTCHINSON AND ZINCHENKO LEFT OUT OF UEFA SQUAD? IF you forget the fact he has just been signed for big money, the Hutchinson snub does not seem such an illogical call. The 21-year-old is unproven at the highest level and, with Nuno needing to retain a balanced squad, he can easily argue the six forwards chosen offer him more.

Yet how many coaches overlook a club-record signing, whatever the circumstances?

Daily Mail Sport understands the Hutchinson deal was driven by Edu, the former Arsenal transfer chief who is now Forest's global head of football, and his recruitment team, not Nuno. Zinchenko was offered to clubs by Arsenal throughout the window and Forest eventually made the move, but it is unclear who was the driving force for it.

Ignoring Hutchinson, though, sends a clear message to the Forest ownership, however much Nuno may argue this was not his intention. It would be easy for an outsider to interpret it thus: 'You sign who you like, but I'll pick the team, thanks.'

Even allowing for that, the omission of Zinchenko is baffling. The 28-year-old has won 10 trophies in his career and made 44 European appearances. He is versatile and tactically flexible. Ideal for a side with limited European experience, surely?

During the summer, Nuno is thought to have struggled to adapt to the new structure which has made Edu one of the most powerful figures in Marinakis' group of clubs - Olympiacos, Forest and Rio Ave in Portugal. It is unfair to judge Edu until we see how Forest's new signings adapt and the Brazilian has tried to remain in the background by staying away from Forest's training ground in recent times.

One thing is certain - if Nuno cannot make this new group work, Marinakis will find a coach who can.

WHAT IS NUNO'S THOUGHT PROCESS? WHEREAS modern managers often speak regularly to players to reassure them or explain decisions, Nuno is old-school. Think teacher-pupil rather than unclenephew. Though highly respected, Nuno is not the players' friend. Those who knock on his door to ask why they have been left out may remain none the wiser.

Hutchinson is thought to have been shocked by his exclusion. Used to an attentive manager in Ipswich's Kieran McKenna, he has found he is just another player at Forest and is having to adapt - not easy for a youngster with little Premier League experience and a high price tag.

When a player joins for nearly £40m, he will naturally expect opportunities that reflect that investment. So far, these have not materialised with just two substitute appearances - though Hutchinson has plenty of time to force his way in.

Nuno spent time with his coaching staff this week at La Storia restaurant in Nottingham to celebrate the return of long-time ally Joao Lapa to his coaching team.

At the end of last season, the Forest boss thought he would need 22 players of similar ability to allow Forest to push forward on four fronts. Yet now he has acquired such strength in depth, Nuno seems uncomfortable with it. The Portuguese has usually done his best work when he has a squad who know their roles - some are first-choice and some are back-ups.

Last season, players such as midfielder Ryan Yates and defender Morato understood their status perfectly and made vital contributions. That is not so easy with players who are accustomed to starting regularly for their previous clubs, especially if they join for big fees.

But Marinakis has not bought these players to have them sit on the bench or fill in for minor games. Though the waters have calmed at Forest since Nuno's August outbursts, it will not take much to trouble them again.

DOES NUNO HAVE A POINT? SINCE July, Daily Mail Sport understands Nuno has been expressing fears about the make-up of his squad and its ability to compete.

But this argument is losing substance. Since Nuno broadcast his explosive criticism of his 'unbalanced' squad on August 15, Forest have signed nine players, including the cover Nuno had requested both in defence and in goal.

Very few managers these days are presented with all the players they want, at the exact moment they want them. Look at the numbers and you will see only five clubs have spent more than Forest this summer, with even Manchester City and Real Madrid trailing in their wake.

Forest also had significant wins in the window, such as agreeing a new contract with Morgan Gibbs-White amid strong interest from Tottenham. Their bench for last Sunday's 3-0 home defeat by West Ham would have been envied by many coaches.

A politically minded manager would have included Hutchinson in his European squad because leaving him out sets multiple hares running, not least among the Forest fanbase.

Nuno is a very intelligent man and has been in the game long enough to know this. His decision to do otherwise raises yet more questions, at a club where the next pressure point is never far away.

urn:contentItem:6GMP-6CX3-RY9G-D17J-00000-00Spain ends emergency due to wave of wildfires2025-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSpain ends emergency due to wave of wildfires


Spain ended this Sunday the emergency in force for several weeks due to one of the worst waves of forest fires that affected the country in recent years, which left four dead and more than 350,000 hectares burned.


"This tragic episode in the history of our country of large simultaneous forest fires in 20 days in a very important part of our country, has ended," the director of Civil Protection and Emergencies, Virginia Barcones, announced at a press conference.
In any case, "the forest fire campaign continues and that is why no one can lower their guard", warned Barcones, who pointed out that "from the Government of Spain we continue in this phase of alert and permanent monitoring with all the means of the State at our disposal".
Read:Spain suffers with the fires one of its 'greatest catastrophes'.
Wave of fires
This Sunday only three large fires remained active, while in the worst part of the crisis came to burn simultaneously more than 20. So recalled Barcones.
Just as in past weeks, a heat wave - the most intense since records have been kept according to the state weather agency - fanned the flames, [but] favorable weather conditions in recent days helped firefighters battling the blazes to bring them under control, according to Barcones.
The wave of fires, "one of the biggest environmental catastrophes" the country has suffered in recent years according to the government. It particularly affected the entire western half of the country, especially the regions of Galicia, Castilla y León and Extremadura.
Four people died and more than 350,000 hectares were devastated by the flames in the last two weeks. This according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS).
The tragedy also sparked a major political row, with the ruling Socialists blaming the conservative People's Party. Of denying climate change and neglecting fire policies in the regions they govern, which were the hardest hit.
The conservatives in turn accuse the central government of skimping on resources. Like those of the Army, although the Military Emergency Unit was in all major fires.

urn:contentItem:6H3B-1BJ3-RWC7-G006-00000-00GOVERNMENT OF CANADA PROVIDES UPDATE ON 2025 WILDFIRES AS SUPPORT CONTINUES2025-10-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisGOVERNMENT OF CANADA PROVIDES UPDATE ON 2025 WILDFIRES AS SUPPORT CONTINUESStates News ServiceOTTAWA, Ontario

The following information was released by the Government of Canada:

Today, the Honourable Eleanor Olszewski, Minister of Emergency Management and Community Resilience and Minister responsible for Prairies Economic Development Canada, the Honourable Tim Hodgson, Minister of Energy and Natural Resources, and the Honourable Mandy Gull-Masty, Minister of Indigenous Services, reflect on a challenging wildfire year by thanking those who helped and continue to help protect Canadians.

2025 has been the second worst wildfire season in Canadian history, with more than 6,000 wildfires in nearly every province and territory, impacting communities across the country and burning over 8.3 million hectares. While the situation continues to improve, wildfires are still impacting parts of the country due to hot and dry weather.

Since April, the heightened risk and impacts have forced evacuations of more than 85,000 people, including over 45,000 people from 73 First Nations communities. These numbers represent the lived experiences of thousands of people, including families forced to leave their homes, communities rallying together, and responders working tirelessly to protect lives and property.

The impact of the wildfires is widespread requiring strong collaboration across all orders of government. Through partners like the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC), the federal government and provinces and territories have worked together to share firefighting resources and will continue to do so until communities are no longer under threat. Ministers are deeply grateful for the partnership of provincial and territorial colleagues, and extended their sincere thanks to first responders, the Canadian Armed Forces, humanitarian organizations, volunteers and emergency management officials who are working tirelessly to keep people safe and support evacuees this year.

This year's wildfire response has been a collective effort. Firefighters, emergency responders, volunteers, local leaders, Indigenous fire stewards, and all orders of government worked together to protect communities. Federal departments and agencies, including the Canadian Armed Forces, the Canadian Coast Guard, Environment and Climate Change Canada, Health Canada, Indigenous Services Canada, Natural Resources Canada, Parks Canada, PrairiesCan, the Public Health Agency of Canada, and Public Safety Canada, played key roles on the ground and behind the scenes. Over 1,590 international firefighters came to help battle the wildfires and organizations like Canadian Red Cross, The Salvation Army, St. John Ambulance, Search and Rescue Volunteer Association of Canada (SARVAC) and Team Rubicon Canada, along with many others at the local level, providing critical support, including shelter, first aid, and mental health services.

Canadians across the country showed their generosity by donating to wildfire disaster relief through the Canadian Red Cross 2025 Wildfire Appeals in Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and Newfoundland and Labrador.

Even as the most active wildfire period has passed, some regions are still facing active fires. To those still affected, the Government of Canada remains fully committed to supporting these communities through these difficult times.

At the same time, many other regions have moved from response to recovery. Communities across the country are rebuilding and healing, showing strength and resilience in the face of adversity. The Government of Canada remains engaged in supporting these recovery efforts and in helping Canadians prepare for the heightened wildfire risks that lie ahead through the modernized Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements (DFAA) program.

The DFAA is a key federal program that helps provinces, territories, and municipalities rebuild. In recent years, disasters like wildfires, floods, and landslides have become more frequent and more costly. The DFAA ensures the federal government remains a strong and reliable partner in response and recovery. Through this program, the Government of Canada helps provinces and territories cover the extraordinary costs of rebuilding homes, restoring infrastructure, and implementing mitigation measures that strengthen long-term resilience. Launched in April 2025, the modernized DFAA expands federal support and focuses on helping communities not only recover but rebuild in ways that make them stronger and better prepared for future disasters.

The Government of Canada is also preparing for future wildfire seasons by making investments of over $800 million for wildfire initiatives to strengthen prevention and mitigation efforts across the country. Initiatives like the Wildfire Resilience Consortium of Canada (WRCC) and the Canadian Centre for Recovery and Resilience are advancing wildfire resilience by fostering collaboration, knowledge exchange, proactive recovery and planning, and adaptive wildfire management. The WRCC will also advance many of the actions in the Kananaskis Wildfire Charter, agreed to by the leaders of the G7 this spring in Canada and endorsed by the leaders of Australia, India, Mexico, the Republic of Korea and South Africa.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DF3-S547-K113-00000-00Burnt Spain, from the air2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisBurnt Spain, from the air


The Spanish Meteorological Agency (Aemet) warned at the end of July of the arrival of a heat wave that began on August 3. The warm temperatures increased the environmental dryness of the peninsula and the fire risk warnings were triggered. It did not take long to arrive, and on August 8 the fires started, which during the whole month of August have caused the death of eight people and devastated nearly 400,000 hectares, half of them in Galicia and Castilla y León.


It is difficult to calculate the social and environmental cost of the wave of fires. Nor is it easy to get an idea of the scale of the tragedy if the affected areas are not known. To this end, Greenpeace has commissioned the photographer Pedro Armestre to capture from the air the scale of the tragedy in the two most affected communities.
In the 80s and 90s of the last century, forest fires in Spain broke records in terms of area burned. This wave of fires brings Spain back to those figures of devastation. So far this year's forest fire season has only been surpassed in 1985, 1978, 1994 and 1989.
The difference with respect to those years lies in the fact that now there are far fewer fires, but they are bigger. According to Greenpeace, the average number of GIF (large forest fires burning more than 500 hectares) has risen to 6,100 ha, that is, each fire burns four times more area than it did before.
What remains of Las Médulas
The forest fire that started in the Leonese town of Yeres has transformed the landscape of Las Médulas, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The flames have burned the characteristic centenary chestnut trees of the area.
The municipality of Vilamartín de Valdeorras, Ourense, was reduced to a handful of damaged houses and many others reduced to rubble. The Larouco forest fire destroyed 60 houses, 15 of which were permanent residences.
The Larouco fire (Ourense), which started in the parish of Seadur, is the largest fire in the history of Galicia since records began: it has devastated more than 30,000 hectares, reaching the ecological sanctuary of the Serra de O Courel.

Pedro Armestre, the author of these images, has worked in 20 forest firefighting campaigns. "From the air, what you see is not just scorched earth: it is homes lost, landscapes turned to ash and a future that is extinguished. It is a country in flames and an emergency that we can no longer afford to ignore: if we do not invest in prevention and forest management, each summer will be worse than the last," says the photographer.
The fire declared in Chandrexa de Queixa (Ourense), affected important protected areas and even the Natural Park of O Invernadeiro, one of the six that Galicia has, which already burned in 2022.
Spain, with 27.9 million hectares of forest land occupying 55.2% of the national territory, is the country with the second largest forest area in the EU, behind Sweden. The environmental organization Greenpeace points out that the abandonment of the rural environment and the traditional use of agriculture and forestry have increased the area of young vegetation,with an excess of density aggravated by the absence of herbivores.
Pena Trevinca, in the Serra do Eixe and Segundeira, between Ourense and Zamora, is the top of Galicia and of the province of Zamora. There the fire has burned areas of high environmental value of the Natura 2000 Network. "It is urgent to manage the forest masses that are the stage where the fire takes place. And in parallel, work must be done on the State Pact to define an ambitious national roadmap with binding commitments, stable funding, citizen participation, a system of accountability and a special focus on those people in vulnerable situations," says Monica Parrilla de Diego, head of the Greenpeace forest fire campaign.
According to Greenpeace's calculations, an investment of 1,000 million euros a year in fire prevention in Spain could mean a saving of 99,000 million euros in extinction. According to the NGO, this amount would make it possible to manage and save 9.9 million hectares, an area similar to that of Portugal or almost a fifth of Spain.
Lake Sanabria
After the fire arises the threat that the ashes reach the water of the rivers, a fear that takes full sense from the air. "The lack of retention of fertile land, which has been left unprotected, increases the desertification of the territory and changes in river flow. The fauna, without resources in scorched land, will approach the crops, and traffic accidents due to road accidents will multiply. When the territory burns, not only do we lose forest mass, but the habitat is modified, where humans, although we seem to have forgotten it, are just another living being", explains Armestre.
In this sense, the environmental organization appeals to the importance of implementing urgent measures to stop erosion processes, avoid problems of contamination of drinking water supply in the affected municipalities and promote the natural regeneration of vegetation cover.
Greenpeace calls for the annual management of at least 1% of the national forest area (260,000 ha) to prepare the territory for the arrival of major forest fires, prioritizing strategic areas of action. A performance for which it calculates it is needed 1,000 million euros per year. The bill for extinguishing the fires of the August fire wave alone is estimated at 3.8 billion euros. The mathematics and the images speak for themselves.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-840S-00000-00The Jarilla fire, the largest in the history of Extremadura, is now stabilized.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisThe Jarilla fire, the largest in the history of Extremadura, is now stabilized.


The great forest fire of Jarilla has been stabilized this Friday, as confirmed by the Minister of Presidency of Extremadura, Abel Bautista, Friday from the emergency operation of the fire.


The counselor has reported that the operational situation 2 of the Infocaex Plan declines throughout the autonomous community, although it remains only in this fire until 18.00 hours. From then on, it will go to operational situation 1 and, in the next hours, if the good evolution of the fire continues, it will go to level 0.
There are still hot spots in the northwest of the fire, where six aerial means will be concentrated today.
At the moment there are some hot spots in the northwest of the fire, where six air resources and more than 200 other troops will be concentrated today in the perimeter, after a night "somewhat complicated" but in which the fire has been perimetered.
On the other hand, from 17.00 the residents of the houses in the periurban area of Hervás will return to their homes and, at this time, also return to their homes those of the isolated houses of Jerte, Tornavacas, Cabezuela del Valle and Navaconcejo.
Also, from 21.00 hours the Puerto de Honduras and the Iryda road will be open to traffic, detailed the Extremadura Minister.
The fire, caused by a lightning strike in an area of scrubland on August 12, has become the largest forest fire in Extremadura in recent decades, with a balance of more than 17,300 hectares affected and a perimeter of 170 kilometers.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88C3-RX18-S0PP-00000-00Mañueco defends that the fire operation responded from the beginning, but there was a "perverse cocktail".2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisMañueco defends that the fire operation responded from the beginning, but there was a "perverse cocktail".


The president of the Junta de Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco (PP), has defended this Friday that the forest fire extinction operationacted "from the first moment" and "without sparing any effort", but has remarked that there has been a "perverse cocktail" of weather conditions and "the hand of man as the origin" in "many cases".


In his first intervention before the extraordinary plenary session of the Cortes de Castilla y León, to analyze his management of the fires of this August, Mañueco argued that these circumstances "have made the work of extinction difficult to the limit of the impossible", for which he quoted the words of the Minister of Defense, Margarita Robles, with whom he said he "totally agrees" in his vision of the difficulties of extinction.
Mañueco began his appearance before the regional Parliament on Friday with a call to "raise the debate" on the management of forest fires and to be "at the height of the dignity" of the citizens, without falling into "noise, simplism and electoral calculation".
In the first part of his speech, Mañueco remembered the fatal victims of these fires, the injured and all those affected, to whom he has promised help, but he insisted on the idea that he does not believe that this is "the time to try to obtain party political gain, or to make politics out of the fires, but to make policies to deal with the fires".
Before starting the session, the Cortes de Castilla y León have kept a minute of silence in memory of the three people who have died so far this summer as a result of fires ravaging the Community, especially in the provinces of León, Zamora and Salamanca.
The president of the Junta de Castilla y León, Alfonso Fernández Mañueco (PP), has defended this Friday that the forest fire extinction operationacted "from the first moment" and "without sparing any effort", but has remarked that there has been a "perverse cocktail" of weather conditions and "the hand of man as the origin" in "many cases".

urn:contentItem:6GPK-WRN3-RS3P-04C6-00000-00KENDERONG FOREST HAS FIRST HELIPAD AND TUBE WELLS FOR AERIAL FIRE-FIGHTING IN PENINSULA MALAYSIA2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisKENDERONG FOREST HAS FIRST HELIPAD AND TUBE WELLS FOR AERIAL FIRE-FIGHTING IN PENINSULA MALAYSIAGERIK Aug 12

The Kenderong Permanent Forest Reserve (PFR) made history of sorts when it became the first location in Peninsular Malaysia to be equipped with a helipad and tube wells to strengthen forest fire management.

Assistant director (Forest Plantation and Innovation Section) of the Perak Forestry Department (JPNPk), Mohamad Farhan Sukiman said the project provides an alternative water source besides relying on river water to extinguish forest fires at Kenderong PFR.

He said the construction of the project was carried out on Aug 7 last year and completed on Sept 25 the same year on a 0.2-hectare land in a former logging site or timber settlement with a construction cost of RM400,000.

"The Department of Minerals and Geoscience (JMG) provides geotechnical expertise for building the tube well complete with pumps, protective structures and safety system, while the JPNPk coordinates the location management, operations and technical implementation at the site.

"In addition, the construction of a helipad by the Perak Fire and Rescue Department (JBPM) near the tube well shortens aerial operation time from 10 minutes to just three minutes for round trips to Kenderong PFR, while also reducing a reliance on open water source such as Sungai Perak and Tasik Banding," he said at a press conference when visiting the site here today.

Mohamad Farhan added that the initiative is a model of cross-agency collaboration based on technical expertise, integrated planning and long-term strategies in disaster management.

"The project is expected to open up space for the development of other high-impact infrastructure for the sake of environmental sustainability and national security, especially in the state of Perak which is rich in forested areas.

"This project is also the result of strategic cooperation between the Forestry Department of Peninsular Malaysia (JPSM), the Perak State Government through the JPNPk, JMG and JBPM Perak under the allocation of the Forest Fire Infrastructure Construction and Equipment Procurement Project in Perak (2023-2025)," he said.

Meanwhile, acting assistant director (operations) for Perak JBPM Shazlean Mohd Hanafiah said that one of the main challenges in forest fire extinguishing operations is obtaining water sources, especially in remote and hilly areas.

"Previously, rescue teams had to transport water from fire hydrants in low-lying areas which took longer.

"With the presence of tube wells near the fire location, the problem of water sources can be reduced and the travel time becomes shorter.

"The second challenge is the uphill trek to the peak which can take six hours. Usually vehicles have to stop at the foot of the hill before personnel continue the journey on foot," he said.

He said the assistance from the JBPM Air Unit greatly eased the operational burden by sending personnel and equipment to the peak using helicopters, taking advantage of the existing landing point.

"Previously, the main source of water was from lakes or mines using special equipment known as Hellywells, which are 20-foot high cylindrical tanks filled with water and used with helicopter bambi buckets for aerial firefighting.

"This area is suitable for the installation of hellywells and tube wells, thus giving the fire department a great advantage in forest fire suppression operations," he said.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-9923-RSCJ-F03S-00000-00Rain slows down the fire in Ibias (Asturias) and allows the evacuated residents to return to their homes2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisRain slows down the fire in Ibias (Asturias) and allows the evacuated residents to return to their homes


The twenty residents of Villarmayor and Villarcebollín who were evicted last Tuesday because of the forest fire which broke out in the outskirts of San Antolín de Ibias, will be able to return to their homes today, thanks to the favorable evolution of the fire.


The fire, which has devastated about 400 hectares of pine forest and scrubland, is the only one which remains active in Asturias, according to the Emergency Service of the Principality (SEPA). Three other fires in Cangas del Narcea, Somiedo and Degaña, are considered stabilized, while those in Cabrales and Tineo are already under control.
The rain fallen during the night has been key to slow the advance of the flames in Ibias, although there are still smoldering points that are being cooled by firefighting teams, who are also working with heavy machinery to perimeter the area between some existing firebreaks. The possibility of carrying out a backfire between Villamayor and Cecos is also being considered.
The work in Degaña is focused on the defense line opened to prevent the fire from spreading towards Ibias. In Cangas del Narcea and Somiedo the perimeters and hot spots are being checked. At the other end of the community, in the surroundings of Picos de Europa, the Cabrales fire, which also affected León, is already extinguished on the Asturian side. On the other hand, the fire in Tuña, in Tineo, is considered to be under control.
The president of the Principality, Adrián Barbón, has highlighted the improvement of the situation thanks to the arrival of the rains after weeks without rainfall and to an "absolutely impressive" deployment of means which prevented the fire in Ibias, which advanced very quickly since its beginning, from affecting villages such as Villarmayor, where the flames were about to reach the houses.
The forest fire risk index will remain tomorrow, Friday, August 29, at 'very high' level throughout the Principality of Asturias, in all 78 municipalities, according to the daily calculation made by the Institute of Natural Resources and Land Management (Indurot).

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96F3-RSY7-J49S-00000-0020-year-old man arrested for starting fire in Berlanga (León) that forced the evacuation of 400 neighbors2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexis20-year-old man arrested for starting fire in Berlanga (León) that forced the evacuation of 400 neighbors


A forest fire declared on Thursday afternoon threatens the town of Berlanga del Bierzo (León), with 400 inhabitants, and which is currently being evacuated, so the Junta de Castilla y León has cataloged it with level 2 of severity.
The fire began around 17:30 hours and maintains deployed 17 means of extinction, including four helicopters, several seaplanes and two fire engines, in addition to ground troops, as detailed by the Ministry of Environment on the fire information page.


The evolution of the flames keeps the situation under monitoring in a particularly complicated day for the region of Bierzo, which faces several active fires in recent weeks.
A 20-year-old young man arrested for starting the fire in Berlanga (León) that forced the evacuation of 400 residents
The Civil Guard has arrested a 20-year-old male, as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson (as there is will and premeditation) caused about 17.00 hours this afternoon in the vicinity of the town of Berlanga del Bierzo, Leon, which is in Potential Severity Index (IGR 2) and has forced the evacuation of 400 people.
About 20 minutes after the start of the fire, an environmental agent called the Civil Guard of León to report that he had seen an individual leaving the area where the fire had apparently started, which led to the immediate mobilization of existing patrols in the area, as reported by the Benemérita in a statement reported by Europa Press.
The arrested has been transferred to the nearest Civil Guard post for the taking of statement and then the proceedings and the detainee have been made available to the Court of Instruction of Guardia de Ponferrada (León), and Prosecutor's Office of Environment and Urban Planning Area Ponferrada.

urn:contentItem:6GYP-6813-RS18-644K-00000-00This Week in Clark County History2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisLIFEPg. B1This Week in Clark County History

100 years ago

It was announced on Sept. 5, 1925, that anyone interested in participating in the Dahlia Show needed to notify Secretary L.W. Bostwick no later than Sept. 8. Limited space for the show, which would be held at the Clarke County Auto Company, was given as the reason.

75 years ago

On Sept. 1, 1950, local forest wardens urged folks heading to the woods during the upcoming holidays to "use extreme caution" due to the extreme dryness and warm weather. District Forest Warden George Beckim observed brown grass and dry ferns, "features that intensify the hazards of forest fire." Beckim noted that, "A careless smoker could easily be responsible for the spark that could reach catastrophic proportions in the present weather."

50 years ago

On Sept. 3, 1970, all Vancouver schools resumed offering low-cost lunches to district residents 60 years old and older. The program began the previous spring. Meals, which cost 60 cents, provided one-third to one-half of an adult's daily nutrition needs, according to Jean Pierce, the district's food services supervisor.

25 years ago
Two quilters found their handmade textiles had been stolen while on display at the Clark County Fair. One of the quilters, Roberta Cook, said the crime was "way below low." Her quilt, "Blowing Bubbles," was made for her great-grandson's birthday. The other victim, Phyllis Shierman, said "they have no idea of the labor and time you put in it." Her stolen quilt was titled "Ocean Waves."

urn:contentItem:6FVT-19X3-RS0Y-928B-00000-00Investigators at Jiangsu University Report Findings in Electronics (Improved Lightweight Yolov11 Algorithm for Real-time Forest Fire Detection)2025-05-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisENGINEERING - ELECTRONICSInvestigators at Jiangsu University Report Findings in Electronics (Improved Lightweight Yolov11 Algorithm for Real-time Forest Fire Detection)


2025 MAY 21 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Electronics Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Engineering - Electronics. According to news reporting out of Zhenjiang, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Modern computer vision techniques for forest fire detection face a trade-off between computational efficiency and detection accuracy in complex forest environments. To address this, we propose a lightweight YOLOv11n-based framework optimized for edge deployment."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Jiangsu University, "The backbone network integrates a novel C3k2MBNV2 (Cross Stage Partial Bottleneck with 3 convolutions and kernel size 2 MobileNetV2) block to enable efficient fire feature extraction via a compact architecture. We further introduce the SCDown (Spatial-Channel Decoupled Downsampling) block in both the backbone and neck to preserve critical information during downsampling. The neck further incorporates the C3k2WTDC (Cross Stage Partial Bottleneck with 3 convolutions and kernel size 2, combined with Wavelet Transform Depthwise Convolution) block, enhancing contextual understanding with reduced computational overhead. Experiments on a forest fire dataset demonstrate that our model achieves a 53.2% reduction in parameters and 28.6% fewer FLOPs compared to YOLOv11n (You Only Look Once version eleven), along with a 3.3% improvement in mean average precision. These advancements establish an optimal balance between efficiency and accuracy, enabling the proposed framework to attain real-time detection capabilities on resource-constrained edge devices in forest environments."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This work provides a practical solution for deploying reliable forest fire detection systems in scenarios demanding low latency and minimal computational resources."
For more information on this research see: Improved Lightweight Yolov11 Algorithm for Real-time Forest Fire Detection. Electronics, 2025;14(8):1508. Electronics can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Liang Qi, Jiangsu University, School of Automation, Zhenjiang 212000, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Ye Tao, Bangyu Li, Peiru Li and Jin Qian.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics14081508. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Zhenjiang, People's Republic of China, Asia, Electronics, Engineering, Algorithms, Jiangsu University.

urn:contentItem:6H50-RBC3-SH0M-P0MJ-00000-00Millersville University: Student, Scientists, Are First to Witness Historic Scientific Event2025-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisMillersville University: Student, Scientists, Are First to Witness Historic Scientific EventTargeted News ServiceMILLERSVILLE, Pennsylvania

Millersville University issued the following news:

* * *

Student, Scientists, Are First to Witness Historic Scientific Event

"Water is so important in our everyday lives."

By Kelsey Madas

Here's something you might not know: There are volcanoes underwater. And they do erupt. One Millersville cccc student and newly minted alumna was on a research cruise 1,300 miles off the coast of Costa Rica when exactly that happened.

Samantha Reynolds '25, along with a team of scientists and researchers traveled on a month-long research cruise aboard the AT50-36 to that area for the express purpose of studying hydrothermal vents, also known as underwater volcanoes.

It was a historic moment: it was the first time scientists witnessed a volcanic eruption in the deep mid-ocean ridge, meaning they had captured both chemical and physical data in real-time. Only a handful of other eruptions have been witnessed in real-time, making this eruption significant in many ways. The New York Times even wrote a piece about this scientifically significant moment, published in May of this year.

"Comparing the footage from the day before to how it looks now is shocking," shares Reynolds. "Instead of the extensive ecosystem full of tubeworms, eelpout fish and deep-sea lobsters, it is now covered in brand new, shiny basalt (dark-colored, fine-grained volcanic rock.)"

With the findings from the cruise, researchers aim to better understand what Reynolds called "a real mystery in the hydrology world. There's a presence of something called black carbon in the ocean." The substance is often found after underwater volcanic eruptions. Reynolds says, "We already ruled out some places black carbon doesn't come from. We now know it doesn't come from rivers through the process of radiocarbon dating. Now, we want to know if it comes from hydrothermal vents, like the Tica vent we studied."

Now, the wait begins. The only way to see black carbon is to test it using radiocarbon dating, which in simplified terms, requires a very expensive, powerful machine and a lot of time. "Samples need to go through a ton of filtration and handling. We won't have the results for a few years."

The significance of this event to the scientific community lies in the data and its implications. "It's particularly important to a team of researchers from Turkey, including Dr. Mustafa Yucel who was a part of the research cruise, where two other eruptions were records. Yucel was a principal investigator on the project, and They studied the aftermath of an underwater volcanic eruption from 20 years ago, and they observed the entire hydrothermal ecosystem rebuild itself overtime - kind of like a forest fire." The cycle of destruction and rebirth holds valuable information for scientists.

How did the Reynolds end up in the middle of the ocean and a historic event? "I always wanted to study ocean science," she shares. When you think about the study of oceans, Lancaster County probably doesn't come to mind. And yet, in land-locked Pennsylvania, MIllersville University offers a bachelor's degree in oceanography, and it's been rated as one of the best in the country.

Reynolds says that one of the reasons she chose Millersville is because of the University's affiliation with the Chincoteague Bay Field Station, located on the coast of Virgina. The field station is owned and operated by the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education, giving students direct access to multi-disciplinary, educational and research opportunities. "I took a summer course at the field station that cemented my interest in MU's program," explains Reynolds. "I really wanted really wanted to go to a small college, and have more access for research opportunities that would be harder at a bigger school. And, if land locked school keeps an ocean program, it must be pretty good."

Reynolds took advantage of many opportunities that came her way a Marauder, including undergraduate research. She was a McNairy Library Research Fellow, a started doing research. "There are often faculty members who are looking for students to help with their various labs. I connected with Dr. Ajoy Kumar, who knew I was interested in research, and I helped him complete three of his research projects." Through working with Kumar as a McNairy fellow, the professor connected Reynolds with a Research Experiences for Undergraduates internship at the University of Delaware where she traveled to Delaware to study salt marshes and how they influence methane production.

Through that experience, Reynolds worked with a professor at the University of Delaware who liked her work and asked if she wanted to attend the research cruise with her, where they witnessed the underwater eruption. "I and some other undergraduate students worked on social media and research projects on the ship," she shares. "My main duty was to disassemble, clean, and reassemble major samplers after they are returned from each day's DSV Alvin dive. I had to take a pause from classes in the spring semester because of the timing of the cruise, but my professors were wonderful and help me make arrangements for my coursework and finals."

On the heels of graduation of her May 2025 graduation, Reynolds' started graduate school at Temple University where she's working with a professor to study Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances, also known as PFAs or forever chemicals, in urban gardens. She hopes to go on and earn a doctorate as well. "Along with my passion for oceanography, pollutants are a huge area of interest for me," she says. "I want to go on to study water pollutants."

For Reyonlds, her time on the cruise was significant in more way than one: "My personal takeaway is that [this type of research] is for me. Water is so important in our everyday lives," she shares. "It was so incredible to be on the bow of ship, sunning or stargazing. As a young person, this was a significant experience. I know my future is in oceanography."

urn:contentItem:6GRY-2DM3-RXPG-R12W-00000-00Spain Sweltered Under Hottest Summer on Record2025-09-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSpain Sweltered Under Hottest Summer on RecordAsharq Al Awsat

Asharq Al Awsat

Spain said Tuesday that this summer was the hottest on record for the southern European nation, which like the entire Mediterranean region is being hard hit by climate change.

Spain's national weather service said that the country had an average temperature of 24.2 C (75.5 F) between June 1 and Aug. 31. That is the highest temperature since the service started keeping records in 1961. The previous record was 24.1 C from the summer of 2022.

This summer was also 2.1 degrees Celsius (3.7 F) hotter than the national average from 1991-2020.

The highest single-day temperature of 45.8 C (119.3 F) was recorded in Jerez de la Frontera, in southern Spain, on Aug. 17 during a heatwave.

The Mediterranean region is heating up 20% faster than the global average, according to the United Nations.

The scorching summer months also saw Spain's countryside burn.

A record 382,000 hectares (944,000 acres) burned in a spate of wildfires, surpassing the previous high of 306,000 hectares (756,000 acres) burned in 2022, according to data compiled by the European Union's European Forest Fire Information System.

Spain's weather service added that the country also had a particularly dry summer, especially in the areas of the northwest where wildfires did most of their damage.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9VM3-RXRP-04RD-00000-00Half a hundred people arrested in forest fires and 35,600 people evicted from their homes2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisHalf a hundred people arrested in forest fires and 35,600 people evicted from their homes


The forest fires of this summer have already left fifty arrests and 135 investigated by agents of the National Police and the Civil Guard, who have also participated in the eviction from their homes of 35,656 people affected by the flames in different Spanish municipalities.


The balance with the 50 arrested since last June 1 has been updated this Wednesday at a press conference by the general director of Civil Protection, Virginia Barcones, explaining that there are two more arrests in the last 24 hours.
One of these arrests was made by the National Police in the Leonese town of Bouzas, where they arrested a 75-year-old neighbor as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of arson for recklessness, after causing an outbreak caused by the burning of stubble inside a farm of his property, something prohibited in the "particularly sensitive" context in which the area is located.
The incident occurred on Monday night, around 21.00 hours, when several neighbors detected smoke and observed that the flames began to reactivate a few meters from the houses and were visible from the road to reach heights of two meters.
The situation generated great alarm, since Bouzas is still confined after having been previously evacuated due to the serious fire in Llamas de Cabrera, as reported by the National Police. The detainee was placed at judicial disposal and has been decreed for him a ban on entering Bouzas and surrounding villages, as detailed to Europa Press police sources.
PRE-TRIAL DETENTION FOR A RECKLESS FIRE
In addition, this Wednesday the Court of Instruction 3 of Ponferrada (León) has agreed to the provisional imprisonment, communicated and without bail of the 75-year-old man arrested last Monday as the alleged perpetrator of the forest fire declared on Sunday, August 24, in the municipality of Molinaseca (León).
The man, who is being investigated for a crime of reckless forest fire, was arrested by the Service for the Protection of Nature (Seprona) of the Command of the Civil Guard of Leon in collaboration with environmental agents of the Junta de Castilla y Leon.

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9W53-RXXX-8525-00000-00Spain: fires devastate more than 362,000 hectares in only three weeks2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSpain: fires devastate more than 362,000 hectares in only three weeks


Forest fires claimed 362,473 hectares in Spainbetween August 1 and 21, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus. The situation is causing alarm because of its impact on the environment, biodiversity and ecosystems in different parts of the country.


In Galicia, the flames consumed approximately 158,000 hectares. In Castilla y León, 150,000 hectares . And in Extremadura, 45,000 hectares. Other regions also suffered significant, although lesser, damage: Asturias (2405 hectares), Madrid (2338 hectares) and scattered areas in Andalusia, Navarra and Castilla-La Mancha. The third vice-president of the Government and Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Agesen Muñoz, informed in the Senate that "it is an analysis that we will have to go into in greater depth and that we will work on, of course".
Impact on ecosystems and protected species
Ninety-seven percent of the area affected corresponds to large forest fires. Of the hectares burned, some 140,000 correspond to wooded areas, while approximately 160,000 hectares belong to Protected Natural Areas and the Natura 2000 Network. In addition, the survival of 395 endangered or specially protected species on the LESPRE list was affected, including the capercaillie (2,400 hectares), the black stork (773 hectares) and the brown bear (1,751 hectares).
Detailed monitoring and urgent action will be key to minimizing future impacts and protecting both forests and the country's most vulnerable species.
Shocking figures in the European Union: more than one million hectares were destroyed by fires
The European Union recorded a record number of forest fires in 2025, which devastated more than one million hectares according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). The area devastated is equivalent to one third of Belgium and marks the highest figure since records began in 2006.
The magnitude of the area burned exceeds the 2017 mark, when fires ravaged 988,524 hectares, more than half in Portugal, where 119 people died. This year, the impact is more widespread and keeps several southern European countries on edge, with Spain and Portugal the most affected.

urn:contentItem:6H6H-0W73-SGPG-H3B7-00000-00Bankruptcies rise in Minnesota, a recession red flag2025-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1DBankruptcies rise in Minnesota, a recession red flagEMMA NELSON; MIKE HUGHLETT; STAFF WRITERSSTAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

As high prices persist and wages lag, people face mounting debt in a slowing economy.

At the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, bankruptcy filings plummeted as loan payments paused, stimulus money flowed and debt loads lightened.

That's all over now.

Bankruptcies are up across the U.S., a sign Americans are running out of road as the cost of living continues to rise. Filings in Minnesota have jumped more than 20% each of the past three years, outpacing the country as a whole.

The trend seems unlikely to slow. And after years of consumers propping up the post-COVID economy, a spending slowdown due to ballooning debt could help tip the country into a recession.

Not only are Americans struggling with the rising costs of unavoidable line items like groceries, car insurance and property taxes, but wages are failing to keep up, the job market is faltering and social safety net programs are disappearing amid federal budget cuts.

Meanwhile, the growing popularity of online lenders proffering fast cash at sky-high rates is locking more consumers in debt cycles that are hard to escape.

Total U.S. household debt rose $197 billion in the third quarter to $18.59 trillion, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's latest household debt and credit report. Of that debt, 4.5% was delinquent, up from 3.5% in the same period last year.

LSS Financial Counseling, a program of the nonprofit Lutheran Social Service of Minnesota, is seeing clients with "significantly higher" debt loads compared to the past few years, in part because interest rates have crept up, said Joanne Lundberg, financial counseling supervisor.

The program has recommended bankruptcy legal services to twice as many clients this year as it did in all of 2024, she said.

Lakeville resident Margarita Del Real, 59, went through a bankruptcy this summer. Her husband, the primary breadwinner, had to stop working a few years ago because of a disability, and the loss of income coupled with medical bills topping $250,000 became impossible.

"It was a rough experience, I'll tell you that," Del Real said. "When you go from having two pretty decent incomes to one income, it's mind-boggling what just creeps up on you."

LegalShield, a legal subscription service that serves millions of customers nationwide, saw a 17% increase in bankruptcy-related inquiries in the third quarter and a 14% bump year over year, according to the company's latest report.

"We've been seeing this stress over seven, eight, nine months, and unfortunately, I think folks have kind of come to the end of the avenues available to them, and they're starting to think about bankruptcy harder," said Matt Layton, LegalShield senior vice president of consumer analytics. "We see nothing in our data that would lead us to believe that there's going to be any improvement or relief in the short term."

Individuals file the majority of bankruptcies. Minnesota saw nearly 9,200 nonbusiness filings year-over-year in June, up from about 7,600 the year before, federal courts data showed.

There were 161 personal bankruptcy filings in Minnesota in the first week of October, with liabilities averaging more than $190,000, according to a Star Tribune analysis of federal courts data.

Bankruptcy filers that week listed credit cards and medical bills most frequently. Loans from financial technology, or fintech, companies such as OneMain Financial, Reach Financial and Prosper appeared in dozens of filings, about as often as student loans.

Online loan providers, which offer quick cash to pay bills or consolidate debt, have largely replaced brick-and-mortar payday lenders, Lundberg said. Fintech lenders typically won't agree to the repayment plans that programs like LSS negotiate, she said, leaving debt-holders with few options.

"It's like, 'Well, I can spit on this campfire.' But the forest fire behind you is the fintech loans," Lundberg said.

Also increasingly popular are buy-now-pay-later loans from providers such as Affirm, Afterpay and Klarna, which FICO announced in June it will start factoring in to credit scores this fall. For many consumers, these loans have shifted from a discretionary spending tool to a means of covering basics like groceries and medical bills, according to a September LegalShield report.

"The old layaway system has changed completely," said Rebecca Carter, an attorney with LegalShield, in a statement. "This isn't just a simple purchasing arrangement with minimal risk. There are hidden terms and conditions, potential interest charges and a reliance on credit that can be difficult to navigate and control."

The Minnesota Debt Fairness Act, which Gov. Tim Walz signed into law last year, limits wage garnishment and collections along with other consumer protections, especially related to medical debt.

A key provision of Minnesota's law is a ban on medical debt reporting to credit bureaus, which more than a dozen other states have also instituted. While the Biden administration allowed states to implement these bans, the Trump administration is moving to override them.

Medical debt "is always a problem," said Ron Lundquist, a bankruptcy attorney based in Eagan. Consumers under financial pressure tend to pick high-deductible plans, which can quickly spiral into tens of thousands of dollars in debt, he said.

More than 100 million Americans carry medical debt, and it's often a leading cause of bankruptcy. Costs are only rising: The average worker contribution to the cost of employer-sponsored family health insurance coverage hit $6,850 nationally this year, and Minnesota recently announced people who buy their own health insurance will see double-digit hikes in 2026.

Though completing the bankruptcy has lifted a weight for Del Real, of Lakeville, she's waiting for the other shoe to drop.

She received her own life-altering medical diagnosis last year, but between caring for her husband and working her retail job, she has little time for herself or anything else. The couple's former life - filled with travel and time outdoors - has ended.

"Now," Del Real said, "it's just dealing with everyday life."

She will work, she said, until she no longer can.

mike.hughlett@startribune.com

urn:contentItem:6GKV-9V83-RXRP-00D6-00000-00Spain: fires devastate more than 362,000 hectares in only three weeks2025-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:42:54ZLexisNexisSpain: fires devastate more than 362,000 hectares in only three weeks


Forest fires claimed 362,473 hectares in Spainbetween August 1 and 21, according to data from the European Commission's European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus. The situation is causing alarm because of its impact on the environment, biodiversity and ecosystems in different parts of the country.


In Galicia, the flames consumed approximately 158,000 hectares. In Castilla y León, 150,000 hectares . And in Extremadura, 45,000 hectares. Other regions also suffered significant, although lesser, damage: Asturias (2405 hectares), Madrid (2338 hectares) and scattered areas in Andalusia, Navarra and Castilla-La Mancha. The third vice-president of the Government and Minister for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge, Sara Agesen Muñoz, informed in the Senate that "it is an analysis that we will have to go into in greater depth and that we will work on, of course".
Impact on ecosystems and protected species
Ninety-seven percent of the area affected corresponds to large forest fires. Of the hectares burned, some 140,000 correspond to wooded areas, while approximately 160,000 hectares belong to Protected Natural Areas and the Natura 2000 Network. In addition, the survival of 395 endangered or specially protected species on the LESPRE list was affected, including the capercaillie (2,400 hectares), the black stork (773 hectares) and the brown bear (1,751 hectares).
Detailed monitoring and urgent action will be key to minimizing future impacts and protecting both forests and the country's most vulnerable species.
Shocking figures in the European Union: more than a million hectares were destroyed by fires
The European Union recorded a record number of forest fires in 2025, which devastated more than one million hectares according to data from the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). The area devastated is equivalent to one third of Belgium and marks the highest figure since records began in 2006.
The magnitude of the area burned exceeds the 2017 mark, when fires ravaged 988,524 hectares, more than half in Portugal, where 119 people died. This year, the impact is more widespread and keeps several southern European countries on edge, with Spain and Portugal the most affected.

This was reported on Telegram by the Head of the Chernihiv Regional Military Administration, Viacheslav Chaus, according to Ukrinform."The aggressor attacked Nizhyn again. It struck one of the State Emergency Service units with Shahed and Geran drones. Cynically and cruelly, on Rescuer's Day, they attacked the rescuers. Unfortunately, a 45-year-old emergency worker died from his injuries," Chaus said.


He noted that a 36-year-old rescuer was wounded and is now under medical supervision at a hospital in the capital, while a 31-year-old is in the trauma department.
According to the Head of the Regional Military Administration, the Russians struck a farm in the Novhorod-Siverskyi district with tube artillery, damaging a grain storage facility and a warehouse.
In the Koriukivka district, a forest fire broke out due to a UAV attack. The fire was extinguished.
Chaus added that over the past day, Russian invaders fired on the Chernihiv region 22 times. There were 48 attacks in 14 settlements in the region.
